If you're mouth has not watered just reading that - something is seriously wrong with you. This is probably my most favorite pasta dish. They did not skimp on the blue crabs (I at least believe it's blue crabs, though, I can't be entirely sure), the lobster mean, and the shrimp. I wanted to save room for dessert, but I just couldn't stop stuffing myself with this dish. I loved that the flat noodles didn't stick to each other and it was soft and just really well made. I loved loved loved it!
I wish I could tell you we ordered dessert. But the three of us were just so full that we decided to opt out of the dessert. Though all of them sounded amazing.
In any case, I rarely give out 5's. For me, something has to stick out. In this case, though the food was extraordinary, the service and the view puts it over my usual 4 stars into  a 5 star yelp review.
Bottom line: I would definitely come here again.. so there's not reason why you shouldn't try it out =)

delicious food, the view was beautiful, the fountains at the Bellagio, classy ambience, good for couples, or group of friends, it is very nice, the food, starting with the bread omg it's soooo goood, we tried the pici pasta, duck raviolis, fennel spiced black cob, mediterranean orata and the prime ny steak... everything was sooo delicious, the service was perfect, the waiter was very nice... the price is standar for vegas for a nice restaurant... I want to go back... for sure!!

I went here on a very specific mission: duck & foie gras ravioli. I barely even glanced at the menu - all I needed was confirmation that the ravioli was still there. And while it took awhile to get to the point where I got to finally eat the ravioli, it did not disappoint (an oh-so-divine 5 stars).

When we arrived, we were promptly seated. However, we were actually seated more in the bar area than the actual restaurant area (which appeared to have a decent view). Where we were seated was ok, though. It was a curved booth that had a very private feel to it. But it was near impossible to take in and experience the ambiance where seated.

Our server was nice and knowledgeable. I stated what I planned on eating and he was able to recommend a glass of wine to pair with it. However, when our food arrived, there was no ravioli. I had been delivered some other duck dish instead. Having to send it back and sit there while the others I was with completely finished their meals was quite awkward. And while the server who actually delivered the food apologized, our main server, who took our order, said nothing. 

The whole mix-up experience seemed very un-Vegas. No apologies, no "dessert is on us", no nothing. I honestly felt treated like I was the one who screwed up (despite being very clear on what I wanted - and it was my sole purpose in dining here - and having witnesses who can vouch to what I ordered).

So despite the ravioli being a home run, I have to deduct stars for the rest of the experience. 

But OMG the ravioli is beyond fantastic. I literally sat there and considered ordering a 2nd helping. Move over Mario Batali - your beef cheek ravioli now has some serious competition. In fact, the duck & foie gras ravioli at Scarpetta may actually be better than B&B's beef cheek ravioli. I'm going to have to that 2nd helping in order to confirm, but I may indeed have a new favorite Vegas dish.

So yeah, fab food, but not-so-hot first dining experience.
Fabulous restaurant in The Cosmopolitan.  Cocktails, food and desserts... stellar.  Ask for a table by the window.

We visited here during a recent weekend to celebrate my brother's 30th birthday.  As we had planned poorly and did not make reservations, it was excellent that this restaurant had a high table available in the bar area for immediate seating.

Drinks - most of us went with Old Fashioned (various bourbons) and service was prompt and correct every time.

Food - most of us ate pretty light as it was our first night in Vegas, but there were a few notable items:
1.  The bread selection was amazing!  The different selections and butter/oil to pair was great.
2.  The duck fois gras was amazing!  Great taste while not overpowering everything else.   

Our experience was great, but the billing (covering for my brother on his birthday) caused quite the confusion when billing everything out.  The receipts almost needed an accounting expert to discern, but everything ended up correct in the end.  Overall 4 stars with a NEAR higher rating.  I had seen that some were able to get a tour of the kitchen, but it did not appear this was in the cards for us tonight!  Maybe next time.

I expected to be blown away by the food but I wasn't.  I tried the corn soup, and while I loved the smoked mozzarella pieces in it, the soup itself was a bit too sweet for me. I also tasted the pork chop with apple mostarda, which was tasty, but again I felt it lacked salt. The bread service was exceptional - breads stuffed with different things like salami and broccoli rabe, served with sides like citrus olive oil and caponata. Service was excellent. Based on the meal, I most likely won't return, which sort of saddens me because I really was hoping for a more exciting food experience.
This place was just awesome all around. Food was top shelf and classy. View of strip/Bellagio Fountain were awesome. If you don't mind spending a little extra this is a great date night place.

THE DRILL-

Come early and enjoy the incredible mixology. Each and every cocktail is unique and memorable. Pick your poison or venture out, either way you won't be disappointed. 

As for the food, be prepared for a sudden indecisiveness to overcome you. It's not easy to narrow it down by any means. As for us, I ordered the Black Cod while my husband opted for the Duck. We also ordered the Spaghetti to split since it was noted in many of the reviews. We both absolutely loved our mains and definitely had a low key food fight of sorts over the spaghetti. Definitely more than enough food, but not so much that you regret ordering one extra main to split. Do not skip the spaghetti, I guarantee you will regret it. If not for the way it is served (under the dome) but definitely for the simplicity, yet amazing flavor.

As for the finale or dessert, we opted for the Amedei Chocolate Cake. Completely phenomenal and a rich brownie, fudge-like indulgence. Remarkably not nearly as rich and heavy as you would think, which ultimately made it the perfect finish to our meal. 

Scarpetta, we will be back. (Probably not soon enough in our books).

This is a beautiful restaurant with amazing food.  We stayed at the Cosmo and the concierge was kind to make reservations for us.

We had a great time!

Tucked away in the Cosmo, this restaurant is intimate and has a great view of the Bellagio fountain. I made reservations through Opentable and it worked just fine. We even arrived a bit early but they had our table ready and were able to seat us right away. We had an awesome seat by the window across from the fountain and basically had dinner and a show. It was perfect. Service was good, water was constantly filled, plates taken away and made sure we were doing okay. Food was so-so... yes, I said it... it was just okay. I had the duck and foie gras ravioli and the bf had the short rib agnolotti. I actually enjoyed his dish more than my own.. but both pastas were only okay. Somewhat lacked flavor, or I just might be more of a tomato sauce kind of girl. I did however enjoy their assortment of bread and the butter, and other dipping sauces they had. That was delicious and we had to have two servings of that. We also had a Caesar salad which was delicious and had a hint of lemon flavor that was refreshing.

Highlights of our truly amazing meal at Scarpetta include some of the best handmade pasta dishes I have ever had. While the more complex agnolotti were delicious and certainly worth a repeat order, the best of all were the simplest: spaghetti with tomato and basil; pici with lobster. 

Appetizers and meat courses were also terrific, but secondary to the pasta. The one notable exception was a rib cap (cap of the rib eye), which I have never seen on a menu. It was tender, perfectly cooked, and literally bursting with a rich, fatty, beefy flavor. 

Service was top notch, though we were in a private room with dedicated wait staff. The bar, though narrow, offered a fine selection of liquors with bartenders who know how to make a decent cocktail. For an aperetif, I strongly recommend the Aperol Spritz.

No comparison to NYC or Miami locations. 
My favorite dish - that I was SO looking forward to in no way compared to the same dish in NYC. (Beef short rib pasta )
All pastas were served more than al dente. 
Would not dine  at this location again.

My wife and I decided that we wanted to try Scott Conant's Scarpetta; what a great decision. The atmosphere and view from our table was excellent for a romantic dinner. We were wowed by the wine selection, albeit pricey, and the initial offering of bread and accoutrements laid the groundwork for an amazing dinner. First course consisted of the braised short rib risotto which was so incredibly tender and rich. I also ordered the beef tartare and quail egg which was top notch but came with no surprises. My wife went with the famous spaghetti for her entree and let me tell you, it blows the doors off Gordon Ramsey's beef Wellington (and it's only a few simple ingredients and fresh pasta!). I ordered the lamb with grain mustard and kale which was expertly cooked and delicious. For dessert we had the chocolate cake and the watermelon parfait. I'm not a fruit dessert kind of guy so the parfait didn't appeal to me much but my wife loved it. It did seem rather refreshing. My chocolate cake was insanely rich and delicious but made me wish I had a glass of milk to go with it, haha. All things considered it was my favorite dinner during our trip to Vegas (among visits to Gordon Ramsey's 'Steak', Wolfgang Puck's 'Spago' and a handful of buffets). We will absolutely be going back. Love you Scott Conant!

Service was excellent.  I felt that my Branzino was just okay I didn't like the bland broth they poured on it. My sister whose birthday we were celebrating took one bite of the duck foie gras ravioli and pushed the plate away did not like the brown sauce on top. A good thing we also ordered an uni truffle pasta so she ate that instead.  Beef carpaccio appetizer  was good.  Ordered the mushrooms for my side and it was super salty.  After a couple bites I've had enough. 

A lot of leftovers.  Would I come back? Yes, but will try something else the only thing I would order again though is the beef carpaccio.

Had a later reservation, 9pm, expected a larger crowd but the restaurant wasn't that busy. We were seated in the larger dining room with an excellent view of the Bellagio fountains show - did not realize the fountains could shoot that high into the air?!?! Wow!

Ambiance was nice, relaxed, easy. Selection  on the menu was great, something for just about everyone. Wait staff gave us 5 star service. Value was a 3 because although the meal was decent, we had read so many excellent reviews and this restaurant came highly recommended by peers from work, yet the food didn't blow us away. We ate recently in Napa at Bottega and paid the same amount ~ $125 for the meal and neither of us could stop talking about that meal. At Scarpetta, the $125 was expensive for the food. We shared the Burrata salad, which was delicious. - I recommend it. I had the turkey dinner special (a Thanksgiving special item) it was good, but the taste was average. She had the lamb and we thought the turkey was better. No dessert. 

Wine selection was excellent. I'd recommend the restaurant but wouldn't go out of my way to eat there again.

Simply said (weird for me) this is the best pasta I've ever had. Tomatoes and basil. That's it.

Order that. 

And wine. Ok, and short ribs. 

The bread is fantastic.  He's a genius! 

Wow.

The best part of the meal was the bread basket, it was seriously the best bread I've ever had. We had the polenta and short rib appetizers and both were amazing. The short rib and bone morrow agnolotti with a brown butter sauce was excellent as was the duck breast. The pici noodles were perfect and perfectly spiced. The flavors were wonderful. The prime filet of beef was ok. We were all stuffed but we had to have the bomboloni and chocolate cake, yum!

I generally do not write reviews but our experience this past weekend requires that I warn others before you drop serious $$ for dinner. Net: Good service, nice ambiance, marginal food, outrageous cost. I've had fine dinners all over the world and this would rate on the bottom in terms of taste, portion, and quality. It would also rank as one of the most expensive. I ordered prime tartare--it was (no joke) 1 inch in diameter and virtually no taste. It cost $22! Our other guest ordered spaghetti and it was very average. There isn't a single bottle of wine under $100. This place is a complete rip off (we dropped $450 for four people) and not worth your hard-earned money. You can get better tasting food, better portions, and a fair price somewhere else. Stay away unless you prefer to throw your money away.

Short rib agnolotti wins for the best pasta. And the spaghetti a close second. Shared those and the duck foie gras ravioli with my husband and we were very happily stuffed. Three pastas is kind of overkill (especially with the bread! The BREAADDDDD) so next time I'd get a vegetable instead of a third pasta. But overall, an excellent dining experience in Vegas.

Had dinner here on a Friday night in Vegas.  I've seen Scott Conant on Chopped a hundred times and he always comes across as a little too full of himself, claiming to be the master of pasta.   With this in mind I was actually looking forward to criticizing his restaurant, but I just can't.  

I ordered the creamy polenta appetizer and shared it with the table.  It was amazing, with the truffled mushrooms blending perfectly with the polenta whose "creamy" descriptor in the menu is both descriptive and right on.

I then ordered the duck and foie gras ravioli.  I thought it would be too rich, but the portion was just right and somehow, despite it being duck with foie gras, was not too rich.  The pasta was cooked perfectly... damn you Conant.  

For dessert we had the Bombolini and the Strawberry Souffle, both were great, with the Bombolini being the favorite for the table.  

The dinner was absolutely lovely and everything was very flavorful, in perfect portions and made just right.

The ambiance is perfect for a small group or a romantic date.  We came here to meet up with some good friends.   We sat at a quiet candle lit table.

The food was good and served promptly.  The only issue that I have is that our server suggested that we order several dishes per person to share.  I felt that he was pushy and was trying to upsell.  I had the pici, and that was plenty for me.  Had we followed his suggestion, we would have had a lot of leftover food.  

I do recommend that you try out their specialty drinks.  Those were superb.

Overall, Scarpetta is about a 3.5.

Originally went to the location in Miami at the Fountainbleu and was so impressed and ecstatic to find out there was one in Vegas at the Cosmo! 

Best spaghetti I've ever tasted (as always). My girlfriend ordered the truffle pasta and it was pricey, but very much worth the $65! 

The wine enthusiast was very nice and made the dinner even more enjoyable by offering us complimentary wine tasting. 

Truly one of a kind in fine Italian dining! Would recommend to everyone who enjoys delicious eats, hospitality, and great service!

Scarpetta is a definite must go! The ambiance is warm and inviting. Everything from the short rib appetizer to the signature spaghetti with tomato and basil was prepared perfectly. I can't say enough good things about this amazing restaurant.

Wow...yummy!

I had wanted to try out Scarpetta having been a huge Chopped fan and knowing I was going to be staying next-door in the Bellagio. OpenTable didn't have a reservation available for that day and I thought I was out of luck. We happen to be at the Cosmopolitan anyways and went upstairs to do a drop in... luckily they had a table for two with a Fountain view and all!

I can't say enough good things about the breadbasket it was amazing. The caponata I could've eaten 10 bowls. 

But I wisely left some room for apps and the main. I had the beet and burrata salad. The dressing on the beets was tangy and the burrata very rich and smooth. It was also beautifully composed. My companion had the polenta. Which was just as sinfully creamy as they said it would be.

For main I had the bone marrow agnolotti. Rich little pillows of beefy heaven. And the breadcrumb crunch on top...perfect. And of course we had to try the famous spaghetti. There's a reason they're famous for it. Sauce clings to the noodles and transports you to Italy...get it.

I was skeptical about eating here after the not-so-hot reviews in Toronto Life, and pretty much everywhere else, but I was pleasantly surprised.
The food was great.  I know it sounds crazy, but the bread basket was a standout - fresh spreads (marscapone butter, oil and garlic, and egglant), combined with 4-5 different types of bread.  Delicious.  
I started with the creamy polenta, which was completely delicious, and a good size for $15.  
For the mains we had the spaghetti, which was delicious and decievingly filling for the size.  I also ordered the Agnolotti, filled with a cheese and meat stuffing.  Also delicious.
Finally the dessert: A chocolate cake which might even surpass the awesomeness of the Terroni Chocolate cake.  Believe it.   So dense, almost liquid on the inside, it was perfectly paired with a small scoop of gelato.  Amazing.
Service was impeccable - much better than perhaps the earlier experiences of some of the reviewers.  It seems that Scarpetta just needed to get in its groove and hire people that are not only pretty faces, but who also excel at customer service.
Altogether a great spot for a nice meal!

Atmosphere and view of the Bellagio fountain was amazing. However the food did not live up to the reviews on here. Granted people raved about the spaghetti - which I did not get. Why? Because I couldn't justify spending $24 on pasta with marinara sauce. Throw in a meatball or two and you would have had me sold. But my boyfriend makes some damn good spaghetti at home and it's free. So I decided to pass on that. Instead I went for the lobster with squid-ink farfalle (I think it was around $35) and was NOT impressed. The pasta was too undercooked and was almost chewy. Furthermore, it had garlic, tomatoes, and basil breadcrumbs. Sounds good right? For some reason it tasted horrible. I pushed most of it to the side and ate all the lobster.

My boyfriend had their bone-in ribeye special ($56) which was HUGE! Although the meat tasted like buttery goodness, he literally sliced almost half of it off because it was nothing but fat. And I'm not kidding - I'm talking a good half of his steak. After cutting all the fat off as well as separating the meat from the bone, we realized we should have ordered something else because there was almost nothing left. However, I will give the place props for some delicious horseradish scalloped potatoes. They were so good! 

All in all, I thought for the price we paid, the food was way under par. I probably wouldn't go back to be honest. Sorry!

Meh. Overpriced restaurant that was both hit and miss. For apps we had the polenta (good for polenta, decent otherwise), diver scallops (I've had better and it's hard to mess up naturally sweet scallops at a half decent restaurant), and a pile of over fried tower of seafood and various veg (awful. Bland. The shrimp and calamari were sad little lumps and shreds. Can't believe the waitress recommended it). My main of duck & fois gras saved this from being a two star review as the dish was truly unique, rich and tasty.

While the atmosphere is classy, the ambient noise and the acoustics from the high ceilings make it difficult to have a conversation.
I really like this restaurant, mainly for its classy atmosphere and truffles!  I found the pizza I had a bit bland but the other food was really interesting and tasty.
I tried the Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli which had a very rich taste. Service was not up to par. When the manager stepped in to serve our table it was phenomenal!

I was lucky enough to to get in with short notice and everyone was very nice.  From the host to the bartender and throughout the whole evening everyone was extremely nice and helpful.  

The food was also great.  Even with high expectations going in we left knowing that we had a new favorite spot.  The breads were great the meal was exceptional and the deserts were also spot on.  

We will be back again soon.

It is very rare we brave The Strip. We went to celebrate so many years of being in love. They sat us by the window, which had a beautiful view of the Bellagio Fountains. The Twenty Bench Cab was delicious, and the Espresso Old Fashioned was spectacular. We ordered the Duck Foi Gras Ravioli, Short Rib Marrow Agnolotti, Creamy Polenta with Mushroom Ragu, and the Branzino. I feel like what I described is the food of the lower class 100 years ago. But sometimes, good, comfortable ingredients, prepared perfectly, and served by Roberto, who had a great personality and style, well... it is worth it. Thank you Scarpetta for making our night memorable and delicious!

One of my favorite meals in Vegas! 

Pasta was cooked perfectly al dente. Even the plain old spaghetti was divine. It was actually my favorite noodle dish here, since the simple sauce helped me appreciate the perfectly cooked noodles even more. 

The mushroom truffle risotto special was so savory and so balanced (truffle can sometimes be overpowering) and I have to say, it outdid my favorite mushroom risotto with scallops from Cafe Hiro (located in Orange County, CA). Scarpetta, you ruined me forever! Makes me almost regret coming here. 

Food came out exceptionally quickly (even to the point of suspicion: Do they make it in batches? Do they anticipate order and make them beforehand? Who knows? Restaurant secrets). This was very much appreciated since we had to make a 9:30 show.

The wine expert was also very helpful with our wine selection. Just name some tastes you like and a price range and voila! Don't remember the name of the bottle we got but it was enjoyed all around.

Dishes to order: Mushroom risotto, spaghetti, diver scallops, market salad

Dishes to skip: Pici (not very memorable and at $38, big disappointment)

My husband and I had a table by the window overlooking the Bellagio fountains, which was lovely. The restaurant itself is very nicely decorated and feels warm and intimate. The background music was kind of random as it felt like Frank Sinatra or some jazz music should have been playing.

I am going to start with the food because that is whats really important, isn't it?? The breads are a lovely way to begin the meal especially because they offer a variety of dips and breads. The citrus infused olive oil was divine as was the extra soft butter. The salami and cheese stuffed bread looked amazing but I don't eat meat so my husband was able to eat 2 pieces to himself. He said it tasted as good as it looked. 

The menu is small but offers some great choices. We started with the beet salad and a root vegetable soup. Both were excellent and the presentations were beautiful. For our main courses, we had the lobster pasta dish and the cheese agnolotti with a truffle butter sauce. I loved the agnolotti - it was a simple dish that didn't have to try to be anything else. Butter + truffles = love. My husbands dish had generous chunks of lobster, a delicious sauce, and perfectly prepared handmade pasta. We were in foodie heaven with every bite. We were sorry we didn't get dessert but we were so full so only ordered coffee. 

If this review was for food alone, I would give it 5 stars but here are some of the reasons why I wont give this restaurant a 5 star review: 

The service was only OK.  It wasn't over the top as one would expect from this type of establishment. Our waiter was pleasant but did not  go over anything on the menu. I am sure other diners had a better experience b/c we heard him talking away with the table next to us. It was strange b/c he did not offer one recommendation to us nor did he talk about any of the dishes or how they were prepared. 

The didn't "sweep" the table between dishes. Normally things like this don't bother me but we had bread crumbs on the table and when you are eating at an expensive restaurant you are paying for food and overall dining experience.  Which brings me to one more gripe, they didn't offer any extras like other expensive restaurants typically do. There was no Amuse Bouche (yes this is a French thing) but places like Tom Colicchio's Craft gives you a tasting to start with in addition to your breads. 

Overall: I would like to give this place 4 stars b/c the food was excellent but for the price and reputation, I was expecting a better dining experience. I am wondering if the Beverly Hills Scarpetta would be better?

I had dinner 2 nights here during a recent tradeshow.  Both nights the service was unbearably slow, the food mediocre (w/ the one exception of the spaghetti pomodoro which was outstanding) and I would not opt to go back with so many other great dining options in the area.  The ambiance is very nice, which is why I'm giving it 3 stars rather than 2 - so if you're not too concerned about the quality of the food and want a nice, quiet restaurant for a work dinner this wouldn't be such a bad option.

The diners: 9 ladies celebrating a bachelorette weekend. 
Reservation time: 7:30p Sat night.  We were late about 15 min. but we called ahead to let them know and they were cool about it. 
Some things we ordered:
-Calamari: thinly cut and deliciously flaky and salty.
-Yellowtail Appetizer: nicely flavored but oh-so not enough!  5 thin pieces
-Scallops: meh but then again I'm not a fan of scallops
-Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli:  extremely rich, definitely get as appetizer and not an entree
-Black Farfalle: the presentation didn't look that appealing cuz it is literally a dish of black pasta, but taste-wise it was pretty good; small but sufficient amounts of maine lobster
-Halibut: on the drier side
-Stracchi: interestingly small squares of flat pasta
-Desserts: Napoleon was popular with the group, Zeppole was so-so, Chocolate Cake was really rich but imo yummiest of all the desserts, and lastly....the Cheesecake....BLECH!

Description of the Cheesecake dessert on the menu..."Cheesecake.  Mango Granita, Pistachio Brittle".  When you order cheesecake, you expect to get a sweet creamy cake made from cream cheese, right?  Not here!  It's GOAT CHEESE people!  So if you like goat cheese cheesecake you'll love the cheesecake at Scarpetta.  Most of the food was actually pretty good (4 stars worth) but because the stupid bald older waiter of ours failed to tell 2 of us who ordered the cheesecake that it is made from goat cheese, AND THEN proceeded to argue w/ me saying that "goat cheese" was written on the menu...uh NO it was not, can you read English?!...that took it down a notch for me.  Not sure I'd go back myself.  If I do, I'll make sure not to have that guy wait on me again.

The resteraunt was awesome. The atmosphere was nice. Very trendy, dark, romantic and upscale. Perfect for dates. The service was quick because the staff is very attentive and polite. Ofcourse it being in Vegas, the prices were high but the entree I got (chicken.. cant remember the exact name) wasn't great for the price I paid but definitely heavy. My friend got pasta and it was absolutely amazing so maybe it was just my entree i didn't love. I would still recommend going there.

Full disclosure- one of the employees treated me to dinner here, so I was able to sample more dishes than I might normally. And I must say, I am SO glad that I did! This may rate as one of the best meals I've had in 2015.

Scarpetta is a beautiful, dimly lit restaurant in the Cosmopolitan Hotel. We opted to dine in the lounge, so I wasn't able to see much of the decor, but from what I did see, it was comfortable and elegant.

Service was top notch. All of the servers were knowledgable and friendly, and the presentation was lovely.

Of course, I cannot remember the official names of all of the dishes, so I will just touch on some of the highlights. 

The octopus appetizer- delicious. Warm, tender, not too chewy, served with olives and tomatoes. 

The scallops- one of my favorite seafoods, and it was definitely done justice. The little pieces of meat in the dish were an awesome surprise, and the scallops were cooked perfectly. They were served over white beans, which were a bit unnecessary, but still a fantastic dish.

We had a side of spaghetti, which was cooked to perfection. Easily the best pasta I've had- simple and delicious.

The cod- melted in my mouth. Just amazing. 

And the cheesecake for dessert, served with a Greek yogurt gelato, granola, and blueberries. Words can't even describe how fantastic this was. I loved every single bite.

Of course, a meal this good comes with a rather significant price tag, but it is worth the cost. I hope I have the opportunity to return!

Beautiful restaurant with a great view of the strip. From where we were sitting, we can see the Bellagio water show. Romantic kind of feels. It's located on the 3rd floor where many of the other restaurants are, near the Boulevard elevators. My friends and I came for restaurant week to try their dinner pre fixe menu. My selections were:

Creamy polenta- this was my favorite! They topped it off with some truffle mushrooms. It has a little bit of a kick, very creamy, smooth, and delish.
Spaghetti- noodles were perfect aldente with just the right amount of sauce. 
Nutella bomboloni- sugar coated doughnuts with nutella inside. It was pretty basic. 
Lets not forget about the bread basket! Your table will get a variety of breads as well as mascapone butter, lemon olive oil, and an eggplant spread. The breads alone got me full! I think there were 4 types. The ones I can remember were.... rosemary bread, sourdough, and the salami and cheese. 

I was very impressed with the service. They have a great system of distinguishing each persons order. For each course, a different server brought out the dishes, and they knew what dish to place in front of you without asking who ordered what. Our main 2 waiters made sure our waters were always filled and cleaned away the used dishes/utelsils promptly.

I'm updating my review to 4 stars after my most recent visit. I was excited to bring my mom to my favorite restaurant in Vegas, but our experience was a little disappointing. I still rate (most of) the food 5 stars, but the service wasn't as great as the 4 other times I dined here. It was, in fact, quite poor service. Waiting 20min from the time you finish your main entree to receive a dessert menu from someone that wasn't even our server, was frustrating. He was just never around the entire time we were there. 

I also recommend NOT getting the vanilla lemon cake for dessert. It was dry and flavorless. There was more sorbet than cake, and the sorbet was bitter and sour. 

As always, the black tagliolini was to-die for.

I went here for a business dinner and I was very impressed by the decor, service, food, and wine. I was really excited to come here for dinner after watching Scott Conant on the Food Network.

We were a bit early for our reservation, so we sat in the bar beforehand. The service and ambiance were great. Interesting enough, we had potato chips to munch on with our drinks.

Once we were sat for dinner, the ambiance carried into the restuarant. I had creamy polenta to start. I finished a lllllllll of it. For my entree, I had lamb. It was fantastic. I also had a bite of the duck and foie gras ravioli. It was quite tasty.

The evening was complete with a couple (maybe a few???) bottles of Il Borro Toscano and Badia a Passignano Chianti.

Being from Nyc I've been wanting to go and try Scarpetta after hearing many great reviews about it. I was heading to Vegas in a few days and realized that Scarpetta was also in the Cosmopolitan, so I decided to make reservations for the group of 8 that I was with. (Walking through the Cosmo later that day I noticed Chef Scott Conant who is the owner walking into the restaurant which is nice to see the care for his restaurant)  So after arriving a few minutes earlier than the rest of my party, I decided to check in with the host. After talking for a minute he mentioned to me that they had the Chef's table available if interested, to which I responded YES! As we walked through the dining room passing many full table we entered a private room with floor to ceiling glass with a few of the kitchen and the other wall was the same but with a few of the Bellagio fountains which was beautiful.  Soon after the waiter and sommelier (Noel) entered to find out which wine that we would like for the evening. I didn't deal the "wine man" but did enjoy a nice Cabernet with my dinner. Good choice sir. Waiter placed some delicious bread (even from being from NY) along with a mascarpone butter, citrus infused olive oil, and eggplant caponata. All were excellent. On to the primi piatti, we ordered a few for the table including the tuna susci, Mediterranean octopus, braised short ribs, and polenta. All were fixed to perfection, the octopus stood out to me because it's a very delicate item and easily under or over cooked. The short ribs had a hard time staying on the bone. Tuna was cubed and paired with avocado, close to a perfect bite. I will only speak for myself when it comes to my entree which was the famous Spaghetti with tomato and basil (unfair to call it a sauce when it's so much better than just a sauce.) Living in nyc all my life where pasta is "supposed" to be the best I'm very picky because most Italian restaurants don't put any care into the dish. QUITE the OPPOSITE, on the record going to say probably best pasta dish I've ever had. Seasoned fantastically, silky/savoy tomato/basil, pasta was cooked perfectly. $24 dollars seems like a lot but if you taste how good it is...you'll probably think it's one of the best deals in Vegas next to the $9.99 lobsters. Everyone else at my table seemed to enjoy their various pasta dishes( orecchiette, tagliatelle, pici). Only 2 problems. ONE the waiter was hard to get a hold off and didn't stop in frequently enough, probably due to being secluded in the chef's table room. TWO my girlfriend order a soufflé for dessert and it was slightly raw, which was taken back. Besides those slight setbacks I've really it was an excellent experience. Definitely would go back especially after missing out on the foie grad ravioli. Soils 4 stars!!! Good job Mr.Conant!

The food is 5 stars.  The service is 5 stars.  The wine list is 5 stars.  The price is 5 star-level pricing.  But who cares; it's the best Italian food in Vegas.

But the music is WAY too loud for fine dining.  Do I want a hard rock band screaming at me at obscene decibels when I bite into 4 paper-thin pieces of the best Yellow Tail I've put into my mouth, ever?  No, not for $16.  That's 4 bucks a bite, and the hard core, fingernails on a chalkboard in a megaphone screaming is free.

The wine list is awesome.  Splurge and you'll never regret it.

Their famous spaghetti is famous for a reason.  $26 for pasta and some sauce.  That's it?  Yes.  And it's worth every penny.

The veal is stellar on every level, with the chanterelles, mini-me artichokes, fruit reduction, a hint of cumin, and sweet breads (my sweet breads were a little dry, though).  The veal itself is all the crispy outside, tender/moist inside, and intensity of flavors you're hoping for.

The coconut/guava ice cream desert was very, very good and light.  5 stars.

The cheese course was only okay.  Three small pieces of cheese the size of my thumb underwhelmed me.  I would pass on this next time.  We were spoiled by Providence's cheese course, though.

Awesome capuccino.

The food was great the service was really bad . It was a Saturday night and maybe they were a little busy but when I go on restaurant like this I have high exceptions especially if it's my first time . We ordered the drinks came 20 min late and the server brought us the wrong ones . When we ordered the food it came out fast the only thing it came all out together and got cold so we didn't really enjoy the soup because we were trying to pick up from everything . After we prefer another round with the busier because the waiter  despaired   for a while . It took another 15 min to finally get the drinks but this time he got the order right lol. The duck ravioli and the short rib ravioli were excellent . Also the complimentary bread was delicious. I wish we had a great service that would've been great .

Having been to the OG location in Manhattan's Meatpacking District, my expectations were going to be high!  

I've been a fan of Scott ever since I've tried out some of his recipes from Bold Italio.  Whom I refer to as the anti Mario Batali.  Conant's sense of `new Italian' cooking is also different from Mario, who, with his love of ramps (a type of leek).  Scott sees himself as adapting the Italian concentration on local ingredients with those ingredients which are local to the farms. 

I started out with the Mussels and Asparagus Soup was hearty which a nice assortments of spring veggies. The polenta with a fricassee of truffled mushrooms was as usual excellent and the Grilled Bread and Goat Cheese Salad were also great starters.  The boneless Osso Busco with orzo pasta was phenomenal.  It was braised in a boldly flavored sauce.  

The spaghetti with tomato and basil seems simple but delicious, a must-try!

This restaurant is in a great spot with nice window views of the Bellagio Fountain ,  Hip and Happening for a Upscale Trattoria and based on how packed it  has hit the ground running on the Strip.

We went here for a bachelorette party dinner during a trip to Vegas.  I would definitely say save your money and go elsewhere.

The restaurant is nice inside the Cosmopolitan but the food was extremely small portioned.  I paid $35 for appetizer special of the day: 2 scallops!  For entree I had the scriti pasta dish.  Good squid ink but very bland in seasoning and also very scant for the price.  Service was good waiter was attentive.  Ambiance left something to be desired.  Someone puked in the ladies bathroom and wasn't cleaned.  

Skip this place and go elsewhere!

Absolutely delicious.  We didn't have reservations, so we ended up sitting in one of the booths in the bar, so we missed out on the views that people are speaking of, but there was a full menu there and we didn't feel like waiting for a table.  My husband and I both had the Pici and it was the best pasta I have ever had in my life. Homemade pasta, cooked perfectly and while it was spicy, the spice didn't take over the dish and take away from the flavor. It had huge chunks of lobster in it and was well worth the money.  Bread was delicious as well, along with the eggplant spread.

Food was exquisite. I think turning pasta in general into something amazing is the hardest thing just cause there is not a lot to work with. The ability to match pasta with the right sauce and meat is and art in itself and this place does it for me. I loved my experience and will dine there again

I was staying at the Cosmopolitan on a Sun night and decided to pop in to Scarpetta after having missed going to the NYC location twice. As a party of one, I ate at the bar and chatted it up with a couple great bartenders - Rico and Jon.  Gave so many good Vegas tips I couldn't keep track...

I get the sense that Scarpetta doesn't book as many reservations as say, STK or Blue Ribbon (my server confirmed they get good overflow traffic) but it'd be a mistake to overlook this place. Overall, excellent food, friendly service and cool scene. I'll be back soon.


Appetizer: Tuna 'Susci' - interesting dish with tuna serving as the nori by wrapping vegetables. so fresh so clean. nice recommendation by the staff and exactly what i was looking for.

Entree: Spaghetti - just very simple and perfectly done. i believe this is something Scarpetta is known for and it delivered.

Dessert: Coconut panna cotta - amazing w/coconut sorbet. not too heavy, great end to the meal.

This is the fine dining restaurant at Cosmopolitan that I've been looking for.  Beautiful restaurant.  Impeccable service.  Great food.  Hip music not played too loud.  Perfect.

We started with the roasted scallops ($17) which is 2 scallops with porcini mushrooms and sunchokes.  It came with some sort of sauce that was unidentifiable.  The flavor of the sauce just didn't come through and was overpowered by the mushrooms and sunchokes.  Still the scallops, mushrooms, and sunchokes were all perfectly cooked and tasty.

Next I tried the Orata Rosso ($33), which is red snapper that comes with tomatoes, chard, and clams (out of the shell).  So yummy!  My husband had the halibut ($30), which came with potatoes.  An interesting combination but really tasty.

The show stealer was the lobster pasta ($35).  Black farfelle with lobster and basil bread crumbs.  Excellent flavor combination, texture, everything.  Black farfelle is kind of interesting to look at, too.

For dessert, we had the peach crostada ($11) - kind of like a peach cobbler with vanilla ice cream and blackberries.  Very good.  We also had the zeppoles ($11), which are beignets stuffed with nutella and covered in chocolate with a very yummy vanilla sauce.  Our latte and cappucino ($6 each) were also very good.

We had a couple glasses of wine which were good.  Pinot Grigio ($10) and Falanghina ($16).  The wine list is a little confusing because they list some wines by the glass and others as quartinos.  But the quartinos are not any larger than a normal glass of wine.  I should have gotten clarification about the difference.  Maybe next time.

The view is decent but not as good as Comme Ca.  Still, I am looking forward to coming back to this restaurant and trying the tasting menu. Hoping this can make my Best of the Best list.

As much as I am critical regarding the outlandish folly that which is the Strip, there are, in my opinion, a few exceptional culinary experiences that you can only get here and nowhere else; with breathtaking, majestic feats of visionary engineering, the Strip personifies man's ability to create way beyond his present environment and envision a future filled with unlimited possibilities.  And when a night on the town includes that man-made wonderland, you get magic, an 'Umami' of all the senses.

Scarpetta by Chef Scott Conant encompasses that dining experience, and out of all his venues bearing the same name, I enjoy the Vegas restaurant by far.  Although all the restaurants are elegant with great food, this restaurant takes the Vegas experience and showcases style with understated design gestures.  'Scarpetta' means little shoe in Italian, a reference to the menu's 'soulfulness'...  Guess my mind wandered to other references...like, the foot fetish variety - shrimping anyone?  No? Too far?

The design is deceptively tame; meaning that it's not drenched in the typical Vegas gaudy, interior so-five-seconds ago gimmicks that cause visual Norovirus.  But once you situate and settle down, you notice the lyrical design flow lending itself to a relaxing, calming evening. By then the Fountains at the Bellagio will have sprung into full effect, with sweeping side views of the Lake and the beautiful architecture as a backdrop for the dynamic geysers bursts - a stunning piece of visual entertainment lasting the night.

After dining at Scarpetta on numerous occasions, I've come to the conclusion that although everything on the menu is good, I naturally gravitate towards the Pasta section of the menu.  I enjoy all of the home made pastas and the balance with the ingredients that Chef Conant pairs with them.  And to be honest, I'm just tired of entrees, they've become burdensome, overpriced and unusually large with the same old formula: big ass protein with some creamy mush underneath it with a side of blah..yawn.  If anything, I'd get some apps, but I've eaten most of them on the menu; I do recommend the Creamy Polenta + Fricassee of Truffled Mushrooms, The Heirloom Beet Salad and the Braised Shortribs of Beef. (They push the Yellowtail as their signature classic- really...if I wanted Sashimi, I'd go eat at a Japanese restaurant where it's served pure, you really don't need any heavy Onions or Olive Oil or Jalapeños to mask the flavor of this delicious protein.....TRUTH).  

Spaghetti + Tomato +Basil: An all time favorite of mine, this dish is as simple as it can get (it's up there with Spaghetti all' Aglio Olio e Pepperoncino) but so fresh and light with just a few ingredients, the Pasta shines through as the main character which, being the carb addict that I am, is harmonious!  It's presented as the first dish, based on its levity and absence of protein.  

Ricotta + Truffle Agnolotti: The second dish in the fete de pasta is a deep contrast to the acidity of the prior dish, the fluffy pillows filled with Ricotta and covered in a light Truffle Cream Sauce.  I love using the term 'pillows', it describes these soft chewy bite size packages of pasta like a metaphoric squishy rest to the head; that, "ahhh" moment when your cranium sinks into a downy cloud.....I love sleep..  The creamy Truffle white sauce has just enough weight to coat your palate without any buyer's remorse and the quantity is perfect for two.

Black Tonarelli + King Crab + Coddled Egg + Smoked Trout Roe: I'm always excited when I see Squid Ink Pasta on any menu - I relish the slightly briny noodle that goes well with all Seafood toppings.  With this dish, it's even more decadent with the introduction of the Coddled Egg, coating every strand with a sticky liquid goo. It's such oral satisfaction.  Oh, and there's Crab, you really can't go wrong when there's Crab.  

Pici + Lobster +Preserved Tangerine + Bottarga: Pici is thick cut pasta, a fat spaghetti, akin to Udon.  It is hearty and appropriately the last pasta course of the evening.  The Pici is paired with Lobster, Preserved Tangerine and Bottarga, a cured fish roe.  The Bottarga amps up the salty briny element while the the juicy Lobster gives a sweet delicate flavor - all the ingredients manage to balance out with the Pasta.

Caramella Milk Chocolate Mousse + Sautéed Yellow Peaches + Praline Crunch + Pistachio Bastoni: Okay, this was a bit of a surprise-under our waiter guidance, we ordered this dessert for the first time... this plate of what can only be described as a kindergarden art project with chocolate squares and pistachio logs....  I wonder if the chefs are so bored that they need to play with the food and at the same time give us less.  And in the end, it didn't really have much flavor as compact as it was- it was like a plate of Mignardises that usually come with a post-meal hot beverage.

Ratings (Out of Five Stars)
Food:            4.75
Ambience:    4.75
Service:         4.5
I went there with my Groupon which was enough for two pizzas. The pizza was good enough but not spectacular. Drinks are pricy 16oz Peroni for $10? Come on.

Yes. I am back again. They should start a loyalty program!

We ordered:

1) Fritto Misto:lacked seasoning and portion was too small for $18. Will pass next time.
2) polenta with Trumpet mushroom: still amazing and love how they portion the food into two sets
3) basil and tomato spaghetti: I like this dish a lot and skipped the meatballs this time
4) Pici but replaced the standard pasta with the tagliatelle. It was perfect.

Service excellent and loved bread basket.  I wish there were some new items after coming here so many times in the last 2 years. But will be back
The pasta is quite good and the place has great ambiance and view but I wouldn't recommend it because it's extremely pricy for the quality.

We ate here celebrating Valentines and my boyfriend is not a big fan of Italian food yet he loved the food as well as I. The ambience was intimate with great view, excellent service very attentive,  lots of options on the menu even the bread was delicious. I'm very selective with Italian food so it was a pleasant surprise and I would definitely come back.

Where to start? Wow. I really enjoyed this restaurant. The ambience, the service, and the food were truly impeccable. Now, you may think I'm neurotic about lighting but I don't care - it adds a lot to a dining experience. This lighting was just right. Goldilocks would have given a stamp of approval. Likewise for the portion size, which I thought may be too small like most pricey restaurants but it was just enough. The food was amazing. My fiancé had the veal. Mouthwatering. I had the bone marrow and short rib pasta. Tasty. And with my Pinot - extra tasty. Now I'm not a sweet person (you can read that many ways), but the Nutella dessert was worth every last cent! Perfection. Service - impeccable. Well informed, classy, but not intrusive. And he had interesting hair. He also suggested an espresso martini, which was palate-ably scrumptious. And if you go, sit next to the window for a killer view of the Bellagio fountain at night.

We had an absolutely perfect experience at Scarpetta. From the ambience to the service to the food, everything was exemplary. Furthermore, we lucked out with getting a window table with a view overlooking the Bellaggio fountains next door. I started with the legendary tomato-basil spaghetti and quickly understood why it receives such rave reviews! The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente and the sauce was delightful. My friend was equally pleased with her truffled polenta starter and second course of short rib agnolotti. The roasted scallops I chose were divine. We also shared a side of mixed mushrooms, but could hardly make a dent in them although they were delicious! In true Vegas style, the portions are quite generous. Don't skip on having a cocktail either - our frothy grapefruit gimlets were superb!

My fiancé and I dined here tonight to celebrate his birthday. First, the food was delicious, however the service was not. When we walked in there was no hostess at the podium , so the very nice and attentive bartender went to the podium to greet us and acknowledged my fiancé's birthday. Then the hostess finally came back and showed us to the table. The ambiance was very nice, we had a nice table next to the window overlooking the Bellagio fountains. 

When our server finally came, he seemed very rushed and was VERY short with us. The appetizers were not listed on the menu, so we asked him what appetizers we had to choose from and he seemed irritated that he had to explain. After choosing our appetizers we also ordered our entrees before he could walk away. 

My fiancé had the beet salad to start with and I had the spring salad with "blood orange" dressing, both were tasty. Then we both had the short rib agnotoli which was delicious, however if you plan on getting stuffed this is not the place to do so since the portions are small. 

Once we finished our entrees after quite some time, the waiter finally came back and we ordered some dessert. We waited about 10-15 minutes for our dessert! I've never waited that long for dessert in my entire life! 

When it was time to pay, we gave the waiter our card. After he ran the card and had our bill in hand, he walked right past us without giving us our card back! After about 5-10 minutes he finally came back! Smh! We've had better service at the Cheesecake Factory! 

Although the food was delicious, we just don't see ourselves returning to the restaurant in the future due to the bad service.

I went here for my birthday dinner & it was exceptional.  I just ordered the spaghetti, because I think that's a good measure of an italian restaurant.  They make their pasta in house, and it was delicious.  The sauce was also perfect.  One of my friends got the shortrib ravioli, and it was the tiniest portion ever.  The spaghetti was a good portion though, and the shortrib appetizer was also a good size.  My other friends ordered some special and changed it around about and weren't happy with it, but I think that's what they get for messing with the recipe.  Their bread was also awesome, it was cheesy with pepperoni, delicious.  I would absolutely come back

I STILL DREAM ABOUT THIS PLACE. 

My boyfriend and I came here one evening in October for dinner. It was probably the best meal I have had in Vegas. Thankfully he made a reservation before, so we got seated with no problems. We were seated close to the window that overlooked the Bellagio fountains. Such a pretty sight!

For dinner, I got the Short Rib & Bone Marrow Agnolotti. It was heaven on earth! Such a fresh and flavorful dish. And it was perfectly portioned! I don't remember the names of any of the drinks, but they were delicious and had fresh fruit as well! 

The service wasn't the best, and the set-up seemed a bit cramped, but amazing food and ambiance! I'll hopefully be back when I am in Vegas again!

The most expensive spaghetti I've ever eaten. But the BEST I've ever eaten. Don't be fooled by the baseball-sized portion. It fills you up (must be the carbs..mmm..). Handmade noodles cooked PERFECTLY al dente and the clean and fresh sauce.. 

Their polenta is delicious as well.. And pretty much all their bread with their little accompaniments. 

It's carb heaven.


But heard the duck ravioli sucked. Just saying.

I absolutely loved eating here. We had another birthday dinner here so we got a table that was overlooking the Bellagio Water Fountain show. We were being a pain to the waiter because we were all undecided by the wines there, but he was patient and I enjoyed their Riesling selection. They have lots of Duck dishes which is not what you'd expect out of an Italian place, but everything is very delicious. If this is your first time, try out the Spaghetti. Sounds plain, but it is really good.

I'm used to the packaged spaghetti and Prego with ground beef and maybe some hot links and mushrooms if I'm feeling fancy. When I saw spaghetti here for $24 and it only had tomato and basil I thought "How the eff can this beat my fancy spaghetti, there's not even meat!"
Reading reviews and hearing the waiter's recommendations I figured why not try this "fancy" spaghetti. It was a good thing I did because it's the best I've ever had!
The spaghetti noodles were a perfect texture, firm but not too firm, just the right amount. The sauce was a very simple tomato sauce but it was so creamy. It was such a basic dish yet the flavor was so rich. 
If you're lucky enough to sit by the window you can see the Bellagio fountains go off otherwise you'll be seated on the interior which is a little too dark.

Scarpetta, you got my 5 stars!!  I love this place. It was a great night with awesome company. We originally had reservations for Nob Hill but we decided at the last minute to eat here.  

First of all, the seats had soft plush leather.  Luxurious. You know you're in for a treat.  The lighting was perfectly dim. Not too dim you can't even see your hands like some other places. 

The food, the wine, desserts, service is top notch.  Wine was perfect temperature according to one of our diners. Well, the server asked if it was the right temperature before serving it (that was nice touch!), it was a little warm but no problem, he came back and gave us the right one. 
We had from what I can remember, Braised Short Ribs of Beef. (Hey you know this was cooked for a long time, I'm not a chef so I don't know this but the taste had a lot of levels to it) Roasted Sea Scallops that I want to eat forever. Biggest surprise was the Spaghetti. I've never had this pasta before.  It was thicker, definitely cooked right and the sauce was heavenly. We had to order 2 plates of it.  Agnalotti which had guess what in it? I don't know. It doesn't matter, it was terrific.  Everyone picked on my plate when I ordered that one. Then for dinner Black Cod which was cooked to perfection. I'm in love. Where's the heart icon here on Yelp?  

For dessert, we ordered everything they had and the waiter wrote "happy birthday" on my plate with chocolate souffle. Sorry I didn't eat the other desserts but they were all raving about it.  

First time I had this type of Pinot Noir. Seaport? Not sure about the name but I didn't get a headache the next day. We were out until 3 am. We went to Marquee, got in, right away and didn't have to get in line (maybe because we had dinner at Scarpetta?) and I was up cheery eyed at 9:30 the next day.
Meh, food is pretty average. Not to mention they were closed by the health department at one point in time. Pretty disappointing.

Everything about this restaurant was incredible. Our server was wonderful . The food was delicious and the ambiance was incredible. Definitely request window seating because we got a pretty decent view as well! 

I got the lobster pici with chili almond pesto and it was absolutely delicious! My sister ordered the bruschetta and the seared scallops. Both dishes were very well made although there were super SMALL portions! I highly recommend this restaurant! Especially if you are looking for high quality italian fusion. 

I recommend making a reservation because we were in there on a Tuesday in the summer and it was still packed!

During my first stay in Vegas I knew I needed to plan out where I wanted to fine dine. After combing through many reviews I made a reservation at  Scarpetta a week in advance. The three stars are given more for the ambience then the food. Our table looked out to the Bellagio and we were able to watch the fountain show as we dined. 

Great disappointment fell over me as I began to eat the Farmer's Market Salad. Beautiful yes, full of wonder fresh veggies BUT unless you got a mouthful of pecorino in every bite it was severely under seasoned. 

We both ordered pasta dishes. My bf the duck foie gras ravioli and I the short rib and bone marrow agnolotti. The pasta itself was light and delicious. The Marsala reduction on the duck foie gras was a little powerful over the duck flavor but overall a good dish. However, the horseradish flavor in the agnolotti was so overpowering it left my palette craving to be cleansed after each mouthful. 
 

I'm glad I tried Scarpetta but based on this visit not sure I would be willing to give it another opportunity to disappoint.

I tried the tasting menu with wine pairing and I nearly died from how full I became.  I ordered the tasting menu because I was unsure about what to chose from the menu - there were quite a few dishes I was torn between and I decided to just give them all a shot since a lot of the items i wanted to try was on the tasting menu.

The food and wine pairing was a great experience.  The service was impeccable - they gave me extra dishes to sample in addition to my tasting menu.  The fresh made potato chips sitting at the bar was also a temptation that I kept on coming back for.  

The stand out dishes I tried that night were:

Polenta - wow, never had I had polenta as silky as this before.  The mushrooms and sauce were perfect with the polenta.  I savored every bit of it.

Spaghetti - this definitely hit the spot.  The noodles were hand made and the sauce was quite simple, but elegant.  A very simple dish but I was in love with it.

Short Rib Agnolotti - The first few bites were surprising, but what I loved about it would be the kick the horseradish that was in the sauce gave it.  Each bit teased my tongue and I couldn't help but go back for seconds!

Spiced Duck Breast - My favorite dish from all of the ones I tried that night.  The duck breast was very tender, had a bit of au jus in them and didn't have a game-y taste to it.  The duck breast was cooked to perfection, with the meat being so very tender and the skin having a bit of a crunch to it and the endive and sauce went so well with it.  

It was a lovely dining experience.  I wouldn't mind coming again and ordering one of these delightful dishes a la cart.

I ordered the spaghetti and was not disappointed. It was excellent. The views of the Bellagio fountains were amazing. Make reservations and get a nice table in the back-don't sit in the bar. Dress up. Very classy place with extensive wine list.

I didn't have reservations and it was a last minute decision to dine here for a party of 6. The host was very accomodating but we had to wait 30-45mins for a table... not that big of a deal but I was starving! Ambience is nice, could be very romantic. However, we were seated right under the ac vent and it was fuhreezingggg

- Braised Short Rib - the beef was soo tender and flavorful. I definitely recommend this as an appetizer. The risotto was good in texture, however wasn't too crazy about the vegetable medley they had in there.

- Short Rib & Bone Marrow Agnolotti - I liked this pasta the best (of what I tried). It just seemed weird that the agnolotti seemed to be cut in half, is that normal? In any case, rich in flavor, the short rib was good and went well with the sauce.

- Ravioli - I can't find it on their menu online.. but it was delicious and had burst of great truffle flavor. Very creamy though and not sure I would be able to eat a whole entree of this myself. But definitely worth a try for anyone who isn't scared of cream & cheese!

Oh yea, and the house bread... BOMB. So goood. Each slice was like a surprise, either with basil(?) or bacon and served with butter (of course), olive oil, and a bruschetta type spread that was very fresh and light.

Overall, very happy with the experience -- but it could also be because i was super hangry :)

This is one of the finest establishments in all of alas Vegas. The service is incredible, it is second only to the food. My girlfriend and I came here for our three year anniversary. We had the Risotto, delicious spaghetti and ravioli. All of the dishes impressed us substantially. I would recommend that anybody vacationing in Vegas come here, and I would advise the locals to live in this restaurant. 

#ScarpettaIsLit

My wife and I came here for our 2nd year wedding anniversary.  I made a reservation that morning for 8 pm. We had the following:

Corn soup with King crab fritters $19

Short Rib Agnolotti $26

Alaskan Halibut $40

Coconut Souffle $15

When we arrived at the restaurant, we waited about 20 minutes on a Thursday with reservation. We could see it was extremely busy which made me really excited to try Scott Conant's food. When we were seated, we were surprised to see what an awesome view of the Strip the resto had. As far as the food, it was pretty good. My wife said she loved the corn soup as it was not too sweet and they actually left some kernels in the soup to give it a texture contrast. The agnolotti was good. It was quite a rick tasting dish so maybe next time I'll ask for a lemon to squeeze on it or something. The halibut was a good dish after the pasta as it tasted very healthy with the vegetable broth surrounding the fish. The coconut souffle was awesome! It goes on my top 5 dessert list in vegas for sure. The service was great. We were seen by our waiter numerous times and our water was always filled. The only thing I would say negative was that the pasta was a little saturated in butter too much for my liking. Overall, I would scarpetta is a good romantic resto if you're looking for upscale italian food.

Reserve a table!
This place is great! We were barely able to squeeze in a reservation during Labor weekend, but it was well worth it. The staff is extremely nice and tentative.

Their starter bread is amazing! They give you a basket with different varieties of bread as well a three toppings: Mascarpone  butter, eggplant, and citrus olive oil. This is probably one of these best bread starters I've had.

The best dish was the Short Rib and Bone Marrow Agnolotti. Cocktails were delicious as well.

Great Italian food!  I went there last night with my dad and sister.  Everyone loved the food.  The pizza looked really good.  I had the pasta in a white wine cream sauce with peppers, chicken breast, and mushrooms.  It was very good.  They gave you big portions.  My dad the spicy house made sausage in a red sauce.  It looked very yummy.  I will be back!
The food at this place is overrated. The service was phenomenal! The food quality simply don't warrant the prices. We had the 8 course tasting menu with the wine pairings and the food is average.

DAMN YOU SCOTT CONANT. 

We made a reservation here and were all excited to be judgmental pricks about the food (you know, the way Scott is on Chopped). But IT WAS AMAZING. WE COULD NOT FIND ANYTHING TO JUDGE HARSHLY.

First, try to request a table by the window/with a view. The restaurant has an amazing view of the Bellagio fountain at night. 

We did the tasting menu and it was TOTALLY WORTH IT. One of the best meals I've ever had and SO FILLING. Second tip: DO NOT fill up on the delicious bread at the beginning of the meal if you are doing the tasting menu. We were so stuffed but we actually finished our whole meal. The waiter commented that we were the first to actually finish the tasting menu in a month because everyone fills up on bread and ends up not being able to finish their dishes. 

Amazing food. IMO highlights were the creamy polenta and black cod.

So while at a convention in Vegas, my two co-workers and I came here for dinner on 10/6/13 on a recommendation from a friend who claimed it's the best restaurant in the city. All three of us did the tasting menu ($110 per person) and two of us opted for the wine pairing with it (additional $45 per person). With all the delicious looking options on the menu, it seemed this was the way to go. Here's what was included: 

-DUO OF YELLOWTAIL AND TUNA "SUSCI". Wine pairing: Adami, Prosecco, Veneto, n/v. The "susci" was the first tasting and my least favorite of all. Nothing special to me. Or at least I didn't get what was supposed to be special about it. The roll with the carrots was kind of gross actually. I was hoping things would turn around quickly, and they did. Ohhhh they did.

-ROASTED DIVER SCALLOPS, MORELS, SUGAR SNAP, WATERMELON RADISH & PEA FROTH. Wine pairing: Iberian Remix, Albarino, Edna Valley 2009. 
The scallops were cooked perfectly and I enjoyed the puree that was served on the side. My friend however didn't enjoy the wine that was paired with it. He's a big Albarino drinker and said it tasted like "it was sitting on the shelf a little too long." I didn't really notice that until he said it, but I have to agree. That could have just been a bad bottle though and not an accurate representation of the wine itself.


-SPAGHETTI TOMATO BASIL & SHORT RIB AGNOLOTTI. Wine pairing: Il Poggione, Rosso di Montalcino, Tuscany 2008. I don't care what anyone says- the spaghetti was fantastic. I'm drinking the Kool-Aid here. Yes, the sauce is very simple, but it really made me notice and appreciate the texture and freshness of the noodles more. Sometimes spaghetti is better when it's simple I guess. I would definitely order it again. 

The short rib agnolotti- dish of the night. The three of us unanimously agreed on this. One of the best pasta dishes I've ever devoured in 10 seconds. The horseradish breadcrumbs were a great finishing touch.

-FENNEL SPICED BLACK COD, CONCENTRATED TOMATOES, MANTECATO & BLACK OLIVE OIL. Wine pairing: Jermann Red Angel, Pinot Noir, Friuli 2008. 
The cod was spiced well, but maybe a tad undercooked for my liking. I still finished it. 

-SPICED DUCK BREAST, ENDIVE, PRESERVED ORANGE &
CIPPOLLINI. Wine pairing: Feudi di San Gregorio, Rubrato, Aglianico, Campania 2009. The duck was perfectly cooked and had tremendous flavor. My friend sitting next to me was already so stuffed by this point, that he couldn't eat his, so being the fat fuck that I am, I ate his too.

-AMEDEI CHOCOLATE CAKE TOASTED ALMOND GELATO. Wine pairing: Quinta do Noval, Colheita, Tawny Port, Portugal 1997. I'm normally not a big dessert guy, but this cake was outstanding. Perfect way to cap off the tasting.

...and here were a few complimentary items our table was given to share:

- BREAD BASKET. It was served with three different dips (citrus olive oil, tomato-eggplant, and marscapone butter). Some of the pieces of bread had salami baked into it, and those were amazing! Just try not to fill up on them if you're doing the tasting menu, because you have A LOT of food on the way.

- CREAMY POLENTA WITH FRICASSEE OF TRUFFLED MUSHROOMS. The polenta was definitely one of the highlights, although it could have benefited from being a tad thicker since the mushroom sauce liquified it significantly, once mixed  in. But great flavors, nonetheless.

- SHOE STRING CALAMARI AND ZUCCHINI. I think there was some fennel in here too. We finished every last string.


All three of us immensely enjoyed the tasting menu. To say that we were not left disappointed by the portion sizes would be an understatement. We could barely walk out of there without toppling over. I certainly didn't have much room for alcoholic beverages for the remainder of the night. Probably a good thing, knowing me and Vegas.

You might notice I didn't have much to say about the wines. That's because unlike the food, they were all pretty unremarkable. I'm a pretty avid wine drinker and I didn't recognize any of these wines by name before they were poured for me, so it was almost expected. If I ever did the tasting menu again, I'd most likely skip the wine pairing option and just order a bottle of something decent and familiar off their wine menu. 

My biggest gripe about this place was the waiter. Although friendly and accommodating, he could barely be heard over the background noise, and with his thick accent, it made him very difficult to understand. Tastings obviously are supposed to be interactive and I had to ask him to repeat everything he said at least once. This became a little frustrating and kind of depreciated the experience for me. I wish he had left a copy of the menu on our table so I didn't have to go to their website afterward to finally discover what some of the things I ate were.

The bottom line is I would definitely return to Scarpetta, especially since I just realized there is one in Beverly Hills (doh!).

Recently dined at Scarpetta during a work trip to Vegas and loved every minute! First of all, The Cosmopolitan is a beautiful hotel; arguably the nicest the Vegas. It's so chic and luxe, you can't help but feel sophisticated while there. Scarpetta itself is also very, very nice. My co-worker and I were seated by the window with an amazing view of the Bellagio water show. Fabulous! But more importantly, the food was delicious! Everything from the cocktails to the bread basket was wonderful. We ordered the berry smash cocktails (perfect and not too sweet!), scallops, heirloom tomato salad, spaghetti (simple yet amazing), short rib ravioli and the best dessert on the planet, the cinnamon sugar donuts with warm nutella in the middle and caramelized bananas on the side (are they for real?!?). 

Bottom line, if you're in town you MUST go to Scarpetta. You won't regret it!

Scarpetta has been on my list of restraurants to try for a long time.  I never got a chance when I used to live in NYC, so during my trip to Vegas, it was an obvious choice.  I was so excited!

We ordered the yellowtail carpaccio and the octopus to share. Although both were good, it lacked the wow factor I was expecting from a restaurant of this caliber. The pink salt on the yellowtail was a nice touch but was missing a lot of the acid I usually like with my fish. In other words it was quite bland. The octopus was nothing to write about. We opted not to get the famous spaghetti because another pasta dish caught my eye which in retrospect was probably a mistake. But, how can you turn down squid ink linguine with lobster? This dish was decent, not great. There was a lack of sauce altogether. The squid ink although pleasing to the eye, was too mild in flavor for my liking. For the main entree we got the black cod and the branzino. The cod was delicious. I loved the flaky buttery meat and the roasted tomatoes which gave this dish some Italian flair. The Branzino was overly rich and neither of my girlfriends finished the dish. 

Maybe this place was too hyped up for me.  It was a huge let down. The ambiance was quite nice, dark and sexy. But we did not get a window table with a view of the fountains as I had requested. Probably wont be trying the one in NY
Absolutely delicious food and amazing service! Will definitely be coming back tomorrow! Highly recommended!!!

I would say, "so so".  Ambiance was nice.  But food did not feel special. I had the short rib ravioli with bone marrow infused.  It was eh...

The ribeye was just "alright".

If you are bringing a client there, great choice.  But for fine dining, there are better choices.

Price is reasonable, but not cheap.  Our check came up to $315 for 4 people (excluding wine).

The view I had was amazing! I was able to look out and see the Bellagio dancing fountains! I tried the chef's tasting menu and everything I had was delicious! It was pricey, but you pay for what you get and I definitely had way more than I thought I was going to get! The servers change your dishes and silverware every time there was a new dish. I love places that do that because that is great service and quality. Definitely a date place. I love it! Must try!

Open Table wasn't showing any reservation openings and we wanted to go after seeing the K? Cirque Du Soleil. My husband called and easily made a reservation. When we arrived we were seated right away (even after arriving early). 

AMBIANCE: is beautiful and we got seated next to a window with a great view of the Bellagio water fountain. 

BREAD: The bread came in a delicious assortment along with citrus infused olive oil, marscapone butter, and eggplant. SO GOOD. 

BEVERAGE: I ordered a cocktail which I am having trouble remembering the name but it was great. 

FOOD: I ordered the Tagliatelle (Truffle zabaglione, guanciale & spring vegetables). The pasta was perfection in both texture and tasta. Very tasty, good portion, & I would definitely order it again. 

SERVICE: was wonderful (because we are young we often get treated with less quality service at more upper class restaurants - no issues here though)

Scarpetta is on the pricier side of Las Vegas dining but we didn't walk away regretting anything.

I'm a huge Scott Conant fan. His food is my food, yo. 

Went back last weekend and the boyf and I went full throttle. 3 pastas! That's how we roll! 

I've never had an entree here, I could leave most of the appetizers (except for a ridiculously awesome gazpacho), but the pasta is SICK. 

Ratings:
#1 Spaghetti with tomato sauce:  OK- how does he do it? It's some pasta, it's some tomato sauce. Why is this heaven? It's tart, rich, chewy- this could be a whole meal. I've scoured the interwebs and come up with a pretty good approximation of his sauce (hint, infused olive oil, fast cooking times, butter, fresh basil, and grated parmigiano play a big role). But that pasta, how is it fresh and al dente all at once? The waiters are all coy minxes about this one. 

#2 Foie Gras ravioli: Very rich, cloying in a good way: super umami and flavor town. This doesn't skimp on the foie. We love it. 

#3 Stracci- Leek and shellfish rough cut pasta. Subtle and awesome, the pasta is again the star of the show. It's silky and coated in a wonderful leek sauce. I'm a salt nut and thought this could have been more heavily seasoned. 

#4 Truffle tagliarelle- Special last weekend. We had to try it. This was almost too subtle. It was almost refreshing, which you wouldn't expect from a cream and truffle based sauce. 

#5 Lobster Black Farfalle- Actually, the truffle and the lobster were at around the same level for me. This was again very subtle, deliciously textured pasta, the lobster was happy, but not the star. 

It's all great here, but if you don't get the spaghetti with pasta sauce, you're doing yourself a disservice. 

Atmosphere is fine, if you can, request a table close to the window to view the Bellagio water show. 

Waitstaff is generally good. The sommelier really upsells his wine, especially the expensive stuff, which is lame (I bet he'll tell you to try some Peter Michael stuff which is like 3x+ the retail here). But on the plus side, the wine he's chosen is truly good. We had an insanely awesome white burgundy and I have to stop this review right now to go look up the name.

An absolutely fantastic meal.  Mike was our waiter and he provided absolutely phenomenal recommendations.  We had the scallops which were truly orgasmic and out of this world,  the raviolis with foie gras was a heavenly savory dish.  The lamb and octopus/ calamari we had were also deliciously decadent. Our wine expert steered us to a spectacular red that worked with every course. And then Mike surprised us with a dessert that blew our minds: Italian doughnuts that made my girlfriend believe in angels, God, and the afterlife. In essence, our best meal in Vegas and perhaps for many months.

Located on the third floor on restaurant row and a hallway's distance from the newly erected Chelsea, the restaurant was elegant with a cool jazzy swagger to it. Warm Edison style lighting cascading above with a panoramic window view of the Bellagio fountains! What more could you ask for? Well, yeah great service comes with your reservation as well. Our server Titus was a pro! He was thoughtful friendly and attentive. That said, the supporting staff and sommelier were equally charming and helpful.  

I decided on the New Year's Eve pre fixe, no brainer right with a bottle of bubbly to accompany the memorable experience. 

Our first course was a tuna tartare prepared with pine nuts and topped with micro greens. The texture was light with a supple mouthfeel. It had a subtle nutty flavor to it tasting almost like a steak tartare, which I adore.  Two small toastettes accompanied this whimsically delicious starting dish, as well.


Second course was a roasted sea scallop topped with foie gras and served with a butternut squash raisin caper caponata. Now I've had my share of scallop dishes and for the most part I'm usually left feeling underwhelmed  but not with this dish. Foie gras and scallops are like a match made in foodie heaven. The thick and beautifully seared scallop medallion paired with rich velvety foie gras and the sweet & salty tang of the creamy butternut squash and caper caponata made each bite a flavor explosion in my mouth. Superb!


Just when I thought it couldn't get better, the following dish blew me away! A pumpkin ravioli topped with crumbled amaretto cookies. The Hand made ravioli was soft and perfectly cooked, the creamy pumpkin coupled with crunchy amaretto cookies was a play on all my senses! The sweet flavor and fragrant aroma also made this intoxicating dish not only decadent  but a satisfying flavor journey I'd gladly take again and again!
