My wife had the beat salad and it was remarkably different that your typical beat salad and she loved it. Next we shared an order of the Cassinoi (sp?) pasta. It was homemade and tasted so. Tiny pasta dumplings stuffed in a light sauce...an excellent primi course. Next we both ordered mains. I had the Tenderloin in the Foie Gras reduction and my wife ordered a main course size version of the Polenta appetizer. Both were fantastic. Also, the bread at the begging is excellent, especially the bread laced with prosciutto. 

We won't be eating here regularly, but for another special evening out, we will definitely return. I highly recommend Scarpetta for anyone looking for a fantastic meal.

Im giving one star for the decor, one for the delicious spaghetti and one for the service. I'm being generous with the third star. We ordered the halibut (over cooked and kind of  bland for my tastebuds) burrata (good), mushrooms (dry, hard, tasteless with bits of dirt granules), the spaghetti (very delicious) and the Nutella donut balls (ok). But I wouldn't go back just for the spaghetti.

No more buffets in Vegas.  A crop of amazing restaurants are making Vegas a food destination.

Must Order:
Tomato & Basil pasta
Duck & Foie Gras pasta

The protein dishes were decent.  

Recommend the Pumpkin Cheesecake to end the meal.
The food was absolutely delicious!  We got the lobster pasta with pesto, the scallops and yellow tail.  Everything was great, and so was the service.  I will definitely come back again!

I really can't give it 5 stars, as a matter of fact, quality of food vs price , most things we orders were not worth the prices. It's pretty much capital grill prices or even higher with lesser quality food / service. Their bruchetta was whateva , and the fillet was ok also. I asked to cook medium, and if came out fully cooked.  I think the best part was maybe bread and their hostess Lydia.

Owner Scott Conant (the dude from Chopped) hates raw onions. Therefore, I don't trust him... half kidding

I think Scarpetta is more like 4 stars, but I knocked off a star because our party definitely felt a little sick after eating here. Maybe it was an off day (we think it's from the cheese in the potatoes of a side dish).

Undeniably a beautiful spot to eat. The large windows display the neighboring Bellagio water fountain show, where my girlfriends and I packed into one side of the booth, so we could watch and eat at the same time.

Oysters West Coast - good, fresh raw oysters. I loved the horseradish sauce that came with it, and a gravy boat of tabasco was brought to us upon request

Stracci - a flat noodle pasta with lobster, crab, shrimp. There were generous portions of seafood and the pasta and tasted creamy/good.

Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli - I actually have to go against the hype to say that it was just okay, and not that great. The dish was a tad bit colder than luke warm, and just the richness of the foie gras/drier duck made it hard to finish the whole dish. Maybe a couple bites and I was pretty much done with it :-P

Black Cod - So soft and melted in my mouth (I think I ate a cloud..). 

Ribeye of Beef 24 oz - For $62, this had better been some good ribeye. Although I know that Scarpetta doesn't specialize in steak, I thought it was a bit overpriced for it being standard and nothing special.  Even though it was medium-rare, the steak was still a tad tough.

**don't fill up on the bread** Scarpetta has fantastic bread. The bread basket had 3-4 different kinds of breads, one of them being a melted roll of salami and cheese (a meal itself). And the bread came with mascarpone butter (LOVE), eggplant dip, and olive oil

One of the better restaurants in the Cosmo. Did anybody realize the restaurants in the City Center area (Cosmopolitan, Vdara, Aria) are not that great? Hmmm

If you're a fan of pasta there is no place better than here.  Everything was spot on and high end.  A little tip, if you're going to reserve a booth make sure it's facing the Bellagio lake.  Everything we tried was really good, but the simple taste of that pasta and sauce is what's going to keep me coming back.  Perfect!  There are so many places in Vegas to choose from, but the pasta here is definitely the best!  Manja!

Having been to the Scarpetta in NYC a few times we knew of the restaurant quality. The Las Vegas location did not disappoint in terms of food, service or ambiance. Our table overlooking the Bellagio fountains was spectacular. The caponata which is brought out with the bread basket is truly amazing. For appetizer, the Spaghetti was incomparable. It may seem too basic to order Spaghetti at an upscale, inventive restaurant but if you love house made pasta just do it! Their recipe is beyond fantastic and the dish is simply heaven. 

For entrée, we ordered a mezzaluna pasta which was one of the specials and probably one of the most delicious things I have ever eaten. The pasta was stuffed with, if I remember correctly, goat cheese and spinach, topped with a light sauce, roasted cherry tomatoes, fried basil and ricotta salata. For desert, we opted for the classic Tiramisu cakes and it came with coffee gelato. The lady fingers were well soaked in kahlua and it tasted great.

Just a suggestion: The wine list is huge and has a very large selection but be careful, there are some very expensive bottles of wine on that list. I would recommend, if you are not a wine expert, telling the sommelier your preferred price point and types of wine you enjoy and asking him or her to make a selection. On this visit, we enjoyed a very nice Malbec after informing the sommelier of our tastes and food we had ordered from the menu.

Over all, the restaurant is beautifully decorated and the staff did a great job throughout our dinner. They brought out the bread basket and described the different types of bread. They answered all our questions about the menu and were very attentive. The whole experience at Scarpetta was wonderful and I look forward to returning again on my next trip to Vegas in few months.

Great view of the Bellagio fountains, romantical, ok food....

Located in the Cosmo, my man took me here for my birthday, so I would love to give this place a 5.  But we both agreed for how much you're paying, the food is just ok.  Service was attentive and our waiter made recommendations on the menu.  The ambiance is nice and of course if you can snag a table by the window, you'll have a lovely view of the Bellagio fountains.

*Complimentary bread basket with three different types of dipping oil:  citrus infused olive oil, eggplant, and mascarpone butter.  Would have been nice if the bread was warm.  The eggplant and mascarpone butter is soooo good.

*Short rib agnolotti-  little tortellinis stuffed with short rib in a brown butter  horseradish sauce topped with bread crumbs.    I love short rib so I had to order this.  I could hardly see let alone taste the short rib and the dish seemed like it was drenched in horseradish, making it really strong.  I don't mind some but wow I felt like it was coming out of my nose.

*Ribeye of beef- I laugh because I don't know why my man decided to order a steak at a Italian restaurant, but he was just in the mood for one.  But basically it was average, nothing wow.  Stick to Italian.

* Zepole- Nutella filled donuts topped with candied hazelnuts  with a vanilla dipping sauce.  O.m.g. Sooo deelish.

I don't know if I"d come back but if I did I'd try the spaghetti.  Small little bowl of simple pasta for 24 bucks, but everyone keeps raving about it and even our waiter recommended it.  So it must have some kick ass sauce and noodles...

I have been here several time for company events. Impressed with how they served the large group. Both times we took over the whole restaurant. 

Calamari, ravioli, salad and beef tenderloin I had left nothing to be desired. The house wine they served was tasty. 

I would come back here on my own.

Scarpetta was a great find in the Cosmopolitan hotel in Las Vegas.  The decor is intimate yet trendy - as you walk into the restaurant along the bar there are several tables set into nooks along the wall which seem pretty cool.  The main dining room is full of comfortable tables although the aisles do get a bit crowded from time to time.

The service was good.  Our waiter was a bit verbose and over-the-top with his descriptions of the menu items but he provided answers to our questions and recommendations throughout the meal.

The food is the real star of the show here.  It was outstanding from the bread basket through dessert.  We ordered several appetizers including the polenta mushroom soup (creamy and rich), the beet salad, and the braised short ribs (outstanding flavor and cooked perfectly).  Several of us ordered the spaghetti for dinner and really enjoyed it - the sauce was nice and light and the basil really popped in the dish.  We also commented on the quality of the homemade pasta noodles.  A simple yet well done dish.  Others had the ravioli and tortellini dishes which were equally good.

For dessert they offer a banana and nutella dish with doughnuts.  This dessert is not to be underestimated - it was fantastic!  We also ordered the chocolate cake dessert which was very rich and full of chocolate goodness as well.

I highly recommend Scarpetta for dinner if you are in Vegas, you will not be disappointed.

Scarpetta is a lovely italian restaurant inside The Cosmopolitan. We were seated near the entrance but still had a good view of the Bellagio fountains which became more spectacular as it grew darker outside. They had a nice assortment of bread to start along with a healthy list of specials that included diver scallops and foie gras, which my husband ordered. I started with the white corn soup with Dungeness crab which was sweet, buttery and one of the best soups I've ever tasted. For my main course, I ordered the duck and foie gras ravioli. My dish might have been better if I didn't try my husband's dish which had actual pieces of seared foie gras. Holy duck liver, Batman! With my dish, I thought that combining the duck and the liver in the ravioli just muddied the flavors of both food items that I found so enjoyable. We finished the meal off with coffee and shared a delightfully light mascarpone cheesecake.

The prices are a bit high, as expected from a fine dining establishment on the Strip, yet not prohibitive. The service was spot on, warm and unobtrusive. Let the waitstaff know if you are vegetarian or on a gluten-free diet and they will provide you a separate menu.

Romantic space with great view. I had the Duck Foie Gras Ravioli, which was quite good. Tasted a lot like beef stroganoff. I don't drink, so I asked for the bartender to make me something non alcoholic that was fruity & sweet. Not sure exactly what it was, but it was quite tasty. The chocolate cake did not meet expectations though. It was dry & not sweet enough. My husband & I did not finish it.

Just okay. 

Perhaps I should have ordered that spaghetti that everyone raves about. 

I ordered the short rib agnolotti instead. It was just okay. 

The foie gras ravioli was just okay too.

Our table, however, was amazing. It overlooked the window with a view of the Bellagio fountains. We got to see the water show several times during our meal. 

Overall three stars.

This was my first time dining on the strip in a classy restaurant like this. My friend booked a private dining room for 12 people. It had a beautiful view of the Bellagio fountains by the window. Our server explained the menu to us and brought out some delicious bread too. Their rosemary one is very savory. I got the Pici which had a nice texture and a bountiful amount of lobster. Worth the price. It had a bit of a spice to it too. But oh goodness I tried a bite of my friend's pork chop and I'm obsessed. It was tender and fall off the bone good. Even the pairing of vegetables like charred fruit that was on the side was divine. I also tried my friends duck and it was very well cooked. Will definitely be trying a protein dish there the next time I go back. Only 4/5 though because I wanted to bring in a dessert but they said they would charge $7.50 per person for a cake cutting fee. I get that it's the strip but that's overdoing it a bit.

I went with a few friends for my boyfriend's birthday. Our table was ready over half-an-hour after our reservation. Not a big deal.

The service was friendly and very attentive.

The food was good, not exceptional. Except for the bread basket and the polenta with mushrooms. They were both so good! There are other, less expensive or equally priced, Italian restaurants in downtown Toronto that I l like more, so I probably won't be back very often.

Yes I'm a fan.... wife and I went here on the recommendation of a colleague and man was he on point.  He suggested i order several thing for starters the polenta and the octopus. Also, suggested the spaghetti. To some that may sound so simple but to me i judge all Italian restaurants by the spaghetti.  If they can not get that right then they don't deserve a repeat visit. Scarpetta's pasta was delicious and the gravy/sauce was good too.  I'm not into Italian fine dining too much ... im into the family style eating pounds of pasta and gravy with some huge meatballs and sausage kinda guy ... and im Filipino go figure!!! but when i do go to a fine dining establishment that Italian scarpetta is my choice.... try it you might like it!!

My wife and I came here on Saturday night with a friend.  The bread with 3 dippers (olive oil, a tapenade and a butter/marscapone spread was wonderful.  We moved on to sharing 3 appetizers, the scallops, tuna and a caprese salad.  The tuna was our favorite, but they were all quite good.  I had a spaghetti dish called Pici.  Lobster and spaghetti in a sauce with a spicy finish.  The ladies had the short rib agnolotti which was also very delicious.  We decided that the Pici was the best of the two just because of the wonderful spiciness. All of the pastas were cooked perfectly.  The service was great, and we were never rushed to decide what we wanted to eat or to finish anything.  It was a wonderful evening.

Dined here for my birthday and the staff did try to make it memorable. They seated us next to the windows to watch the Bellagio fountains at sunset. 
We ordered the mushrooms and polenta for an appetizer. I could not stop eating it! Creamy polenta, completely smooth, mushrooms in a jus- I wanted to drink the sauce. Rich, thick, savory. Be sure to order that. 
We both ordered the short rib agnolotti for our main dish. It does say it has horseradish it the dish but we were expecting just a hint of it. It was overwhelming. That was all you could taste. That's why the 3 star rating. 
They did bring me a dessert tasting menu for my birthday that was delicious. 
I would go here again, but would order a different main dish.

Normally, I'm not an Italian foodie fan -- my man and I lean towards Asian flavors.... so when Scarpetta was suggested for a business meal, I rolled my eyes and thought: oh well.  Wow, I was wrong!!  Ambiance is everything you expect from a Strip resto -- seductive and stylish, modern but comfortable... the list goes on.  The wine was fantastic, as was everything I ordered (read: tuna 'susci;' their special pasta of the day made with squid ink -- app. portion, if you please; and the branzino... WOW!) Didn't think I had any room for dessert... but made room for heaven when it came to the table -- the zeppole was all that... and then some.  Service was sometimes slow, though the servers themselves were extremely knowledgeable about the menu and were quick to make suggestions once given info about preferences. Love this place and can't wait to go back!

I came here with a slightly odd combination of diners - my husband, his parents, and my cousin and his girlfriend.  Yet between the food and ambiance, I had a great time.

One of my complaints during my time living in Toronto was that there wasn't much memorable food.  Granted, when I was a student I would in no way have been able to afford to eat here, but now for a special occasion I'd highly recommend it.  Scott Conant got rave reviews when Scarpetta opened in New York, and finally, another great chef has opted to open up an outpost to the north.

The restaurant is located in the Thompson hotel and is all forms of swanky.  The booths are round and go around a serpentine piece of wood.  The interior is very modern yet also airy.

We were promptly served delicious homemade bread with tapenade and a delicious butter-mascarpone spread.  We split a few appetizers, including the Tuna "susci" and the hamachi crudo.  Both were really fresh and delicious.  My husband and his dad opted to split a squid dish and were also fans of that.

Now, for the entree there weren't too many non-meat options, so I stuck with the spaghetti with tomato & basil.  I'm not the biggest fan of basil, and I usually opt for thinner pastas than spaghetti, so I didn't know how well this would fly.  But no, this is what pasta is, people.  It was a perfect al dente - not too mushy, but also not too hard.  The sauce was luscious and creamy and the basil tasted fresh and didn't overpower the sauce in the slightest.  And while the portion size is not nearly as large as what you'll get at a generic red-sauce restaurant, it was still plenty large to fill me up.

Everyone else also enjoyed their dishes, though I can't recall exactly what they ordered.  The service was very attentive and our water glasses were constantly refilled.

The meal wound up being pricey since some members of our group chose to have wine or cocktails (when we eat out solo, J & I rarely order drinks) but the entrees themselves were on the high side of moderate.  The only other fine-ish dining place I've been to in TO is Susur Lee's Lee, so I'd definitely be up for adding Scarpetta to my "special occasion Toronto eateries."

I originally went to Scarpetta in New York and LOVED it. After moving to Los Angeles, I went to the one in Beverly Hills pretty often (until they closed recently) and enjoyed every experience there, too.

We got to Vegas fairly late on a Friday night and I was excited to find out that Scarpetta was still open. We were seated quickly and I knew everything that I wanted to order (short rib risotto, spaghetti, and the chicken). 

Directly in front of our table, there was a table of 4, one person that was visibly very intoxicated. I wasn't surprised at all since it is Vegas and a Friday night. However, the waiter kept serving the entire table more wine, even as this guy was slurring and barely able to hold himself up. 

I'm halfway into my risotto when I notice him put his head down on the table. The restaurant is fairly empty at this point so there are a lot of staff just standing around. By the time I'm done with the risotto, he's completely lying down in his booth. My spaghetti comes out, and as I take a bite of my delicious food, I look up to see the guy projectile vomit. It's splashing all over the booth and the sound is as gross as the actual view.

The staff get over there and start cleaning up and a few minutes later, someone stops by at our table to see how we're doing. I tell him we've obviously lost our appetite and he asks if we would like our plates (which are nearly untouched) packed up. They bring us our food in to go boxes along with the bill.

So I'm not an unreasonable person. I don't blame Scarpetta for a drunk person in Vegas on a Friday night. The issue I have is that they continued to serve drinks to him, leading to him vomiting in front of other patrons. After that, we don't even get an apology, the manager doesn't stop by, and we're asked to pay for the entire bill. 

The situation was handled poorly by their staff, and I still had to pay for the entire crappy experience.

I loved Scarpetta in New York, and the one in Las Vegas did not disappoint. The food, atmosphere, and service were all incredible. They seated us by the window, so we could enjoy the Bellagio fountain show every 15 minutes. 

All of the food was fantastic, including the bread basket they bring out in the beginning. Our starters were the grilled octopus and beef carpaccio. The beef carpaccio definitely stole the show, and went great with the accompanying parmesan crisps. I got the foie gras duck ravioli, which was solid and full of flavor. My bf got the short rib agnolotti, and if I could do it over again I would have done the same. While my ravioli was good, the agnolotti was excellent. Either way, you can't go wrong with their fresh-made pastas. 

Unfortunately we were too full to get more than a glass of wine or dessert (thanks to an all you can eat brunch buffet), but I'm sure the dessert and cocktails would have been great. If I am in NY or Las Vegas, I will definitely come back to Scarpetta!

I can truly say that I've had a complete Cinderella experience here during my sister's Bachelorette party. Our host Bex was amazing and truly opened the door for us to experiencing the world of V.I.P.! The staff was very polite and helpful. Our private room was spectacular-we had an amazing view of the Belagio Fountain!

The executive sous chef came out to talk to us and gave us an intro on their specialties. I am the type of person who cannot make up their mind on what to order so the chef gave me some suggestions and there we began our round of unforgettable appetizers. 

I definitely lived it up that night-felt so important and spoiled to have the staff wait on us the way they did. Small details like having the chair pulled out for you, the napkin laid across your lap, even the pretty bottles of water all added up.

The food, of course, was other worldly. Everything from the main course to the desserts were such a dream. I could not believe I was eating all the delicious food that I see hyped up so much on tv. 

I notice a lot of small details and absolutely everything-even the atmosphere as well as the design of the restaurant was beautiful, unique, and classy. The whole experience at Scarpetta exceeded above and beyond in all areas. I have never been so pampered my whole life and I simply CANNOT and will NOT do Vegas any other way! I highly recommend!!!!!

This place was definitely overpriced for the food. My boss was not too happy at all with the food. We took one of our colleagues who was born and raised and still goes back and forth from Italy and he did not like the food for the price. The service, however was amazing and so was the view. Definitely s romantic place.

Great fine dining! Love the atmosphere! Was here was my husband and did a full tasting with wine pairing and to my surprise portions by the time you hit the 4th course it was definitely filling! Had a romantic table overlooking the Bellagio so it was really nice! It's pricey but well worth it!

Came back again with just my 8 year old daughter for mommy and me getaway and my little one has a fine palette! The best thing still is their spaghetti!

Service is always good but regardless you repaying to be a a fine dining place and atmosphere. We also stayed at the Cosmo and ll their rest is to only convenient but all delicious!

Social hour review.

My friends and I decided to check out the Social Hour at the Cosmo. It was everything you expect it to be: dark, trendy, sexy. The drink menu for Social Hour was kind of limited, but it had options that I liked sooooo works for me.

They put chips out on the bar that I could not stop eating because what even is willpower.

Definitely recommend for a trendy drink spot during social hour.

This was our fancy splurge celebration dinner while we were in Vegas. I tried to make reservations for 10 online through their website, but I was told that there were no reservations available within 2.5 hours of our reservation time (830pm on a Sunday) for 8 weeks. I called instead, and they were able to accommodate us. 

When we got there, we had to wait for a little while for them to get our table together, but the cocktail menu was beautiful. I indulged in the Gallardo, Hendrick's apple, lime, and basil. It was fresh and clean, really light and flavorful. It also came with a basil leaf floating in it, and was gorgeous. 

When they seated us, they'd given us a private dining room for our large group, and we had an amazing server who was knowledgeable, friendly, and willing to make suggestions. 

The meal started with fresh baked rosemary bread served with a trip of condiments. There was soft, whipped marscapone butter, a rich eggplant tapenade, and simple quality olive oil. I order the spring pea soup with dungeness crab, almonds, and pea tendrils as a starter. It was so delicate, fresh, and really lovely. It tasted like spring. The crunch and nutty flavor from the almonds and the sweet meaty taste of the shredded crab was such a nice balance of the pea flavor. It was spring green, and melted in my mouth. I'm not even a huge fan of peas, but this is such a good example of how fresh, high-quality ingredients can elevate something simple to culinary art. 

For dinner, I had the Pici with lobster that the server suggested. This is the best pasta I've ever eaten. And I've eaten a lot of pasta. It's house made and fresh, and this is how al dente is supposed to be. It's firm and chewy, but still delicate and flavorful. It was made with tarragon, so it was green and herby. The pesto was made of almonds and chili, so it had a little spice to it. I could've handled more spice, though. There was almost no heat, but it's OK because the other flavors were so perfect. This is also the best cooked lobster I've ever had. I'm used to lobster in butter, or pieces so small thrown into dishes to give them an upscale feel, but these were beautiful, pink large pieces of lobster. They still benefited from the fat in the olive oil pesto, and it brought out lobster flavors I hadn't tasted before. They were tender and meaty, and balanced well with the pasta and pesto. It was simply one of the best pasta meals I've ever had in my life.

One of the house specialties is spaghetti with tomato and basil. Sounds easy, right? Once again, one of the best pasta dishes I've ever had in my life. The ingredients and technique are so high-quality that they elevate even the simplest meals into a once-in-a-lifetime experience. 

The filet was tender and flavorful, although my companion felt is was little more medium-well than the medium he ordered. The potato puree it rested on absorbed the steak juices and every bite tasted luxurious. 

The honey glazed carrots with toasted pistachios were roasted to perfection. They were soft, but not limp or mushy, and the pistachios added a pleasant nutty crunch. They were sweet, but not cloying, and well balanced. Again, I'm not a huge carrot fan, but these made me a believer. 

My one 21st-century complaint is the lights are so low, I wasn't able to get great pictures, but really, that's probably a plus. It was intimate and romantic. 

Indulge at Scarpetta and you won't regret it. Take your time and savor the flavors at this masterful restaurant. There's a lot of work and knowledge going into these meals, and if you're privileged enough to eat here, relish every bite.

Food was phenomenal. The bread was very fresh and spreads were great. I had the lobster ravioli and demolished it. The portions were perfect but higher pricing. 

The wine by the glass list was disappointing. Out of al the bottle options, you would think the glass list would be more fruitful but it was very limited. 

Service was great and everyone was attentive. Great ambiance and we had a great view of the bellagio water show!

Went to Scarpetta for Winterlicious this year. I did dine there previously yet my review is still the same- just okay.

For my starter I go the Braised Short Beef Ribs- these were real good, fall off of the bone and delicious, however the risotto that came with it was not that great. It was just fine. If they just gave me the beef, I would have enjoyed it so much more.

My second course was the Organic Chicken. The first breast it came with was amazing. The crispy layer on time is a wonderful touch. However when it came the my second and third piece it seemed like the end bites were undercooked and were very chewy and slimy...had to force it down. 

The last part was dessert. I had the Coconut Panacotta. Let me say this was tres yummy. It also came with a coconut ice cream which was equally as good. This was the high light of the meal.

The atmosphere at Scarpetta is very snooty. I mean the price tag matches it, when I went their last time my meal cost $100 + tip, Winterlicious helped me dine with half the price tag!  Service was decent. The waiter forgot my drink and admitted he did, also I originally asked to change my reservation, they stated it couldn't be done, yet when I was there it wasn't packed, there were multiple tables so they could have switched it for me. Also, I was sat at a pretty not so hot table, I mean cut me some slack, its not packed there give me a good table.

So based on all of those factors its a 3. Had they switched my reservation, brought me my drink, and had a tad better food, they would be a 4, but they didn't

Been to Scarpetta in both LV and NY and this place doesn't disappoint! Everything I've tried has packed so much flavor. In LV we had the duck & foie gras ravioli, the beet salad, the uni & lobster tagliolini, and the branzino. Everything came out perfect. My fave of the night was definitely the uni & lobster pasta -- SO GOOD. Creamy but not overly rich, and the roe added nice texture to the dish. Can't wait to come back to this restaurant! FYI, corkage fee is $35.

I've been meaning to try Scarpetta for over five years and I'm very glad I did. 
When I sat down I ended up waiting for seven minutes, no water, no menu. (I had reservations too)
Servers kept looking at me and it was almost 10pm so not a super packed house. 
No apology for the wait, and especially dining alone, they should have at least given me a menu or some water. I would have left if it hit the 10 minute mark but I was here for the food.

The food definitely delivers, and it was some of the best pasta I have ever had and reminded me of my time in Italy. The flavor of the pasta took me back. I had the short rib - bone marrow agnolotti. The crunch on top made the entire dish that much better.

Also order the diver scallops with foie gras. Very rich, but the marriage of flavors works beautifully. 

Nutella and vanilla bomboloni -with banana ice cream. Yup. It's good. It's really good. 

I give this location a 4.5/5 stars.
Seriously love this place. Tend to come here allot after work and the food is always amazing and so good!!

My number one, oh wow, surprisingly fantastic meal of my most recent Vegas trip. I say suprisingly because we came here on a whim after the group decided we wanted Italian for dinner. Based on the yelp reviews, and the fact that they are in the posh Cosmo, we were able to make a last minute reservations. 
    The uber contemporary interior was very inviting while giving some great views of the strip and the bellagio fountains. The star of this dinner was by far the spaghetti. The absolute best cooked pasta I have ever had.  The best. House made pasta cooked to a perfect al dente. It actually had that slight "crunch" a perfect pasta should have, but raaaaarely does. All the other pastas were fantastic as well.  Scarpetta is a perfect combination of style and execution. I would say a must try.

There is nothing to hate at Scarpetta. 

The service, views, food and ambiance were top rate. We had the scallop appetizer, and instead of us sharing off one plate, they put one scallop on each of our plates so we could individually taste what a perfectly cooked and garnished scallop tastes like. 

Next, my husband had the foie gras ravioli which he didn't shovel into his mouth because he wanted to enjoy and savor each bite. I had the gluten free spaghetti with tomato and basil sauce. You'd think something so simple wouldn't get your heart racing, but there was nothing simple about the flavor of this beautifully done dish. 

Finally, we ended with the gluten free chocolate cake with toasted almond gelato and salted caramel sauce. This was not the dinky salted caramel sauce you get at a coffee shop - this is the sauce that ruins all sauces on desserts. If it wasn't so upscale, I probably would have licked the plate and asked for a gallon of this sauce. The gelato had a perfect rich, creamy texture, and it complimented the cake and the sauce instead of taking over the plate. The textures and taste of this cake alone is a reason to come here. 

Everything about Scarpetta is excellent. Try to get a table near the windows to catch views of the Bellagio Fountains while you enjoy some of the best food in Vegas.

As guest we felt like a burden instead of welcomed and we found the foods  we tried as one dimensional and under seasoned , flat and the dessert awful . Maybe they just weren't in the working flow of things yet or maybe it just was an off night I don't know.

The door was wide open at 5:25 so we walked in and the hostess told us to make a reservation for 5:30 and to leave and come back in a few minutes . We thought that seemed odd but thought it was just because she was very young and figured that was all it was and came back a few minutes latter .

Too start with I received a white lint filled napkin on top of my black pants , but I did notice they have black linen napkins they use for the wine bottles. 

We felt uncomfortable the whole time dining because most of the time I saw up to eleven members of staff were standing across from us with their backs against the wall just looking out into our direction . I glared at them a few times but they didn't budge .

We started with the tuna susci -described as marinated vegetables with preserved truffles , everything was raw and everything had little taste.

We shared the short rib agnolotti , that were like mini raviolis filled with short rib that had a baby food texture inside the well made pasta. Maybe ten percent of the  agnolottis we topped with a scant amount of toasted  crumbs slightly laced with horseradish for flavor that were resting in some browned butter.

The black cod although cooked nicely would have been forgettable but was not , only because of the concentrated tomato that I found interesting .  this dish was extremely mild and under seasoned with a few pieces of fennel that were nicely caramelized .

My husband had the duck breast and he said it was his least favorite one he ever had since the skin wasn't crispy and also lacked flavor , he thought it wasn't seasoned at all .

We had a little time to kill before the show so we thought maybe dessert might be good . We ordered the zeppole I don't mean to be mean or disrespectful but honest to God they tasted just like the chocolate muffins of the Sweet Tomatoes salad bar buffet , the zeppole were bread like , not sweet , almost not chocolate flavored and only a few zeppole not all had essence of nutella in them . 

At this price range they don't have this much room for error.

Lovely surprise.

Randomly picked this place to take my boss and another colleague. 

Ordered the Spaghetti (tomato & basil) based on the server's recommendation. Have to admit thought it was rather bold of the dude to suggest the spaghetti as the pasta to try. But it was very good, al dente handmade noodles with the right balance of sweet and acidity of the tomato & basil sauce. 

Also the field greens was rather good even though it wasn't listed on the menu. There is a smear of some kind of nut butter, candied walnut and uber fresh greens with light vinaigrette salad.

Very attentive staff, gorgeous decor (albeit a bit dark), quality food:

Braised short ribs with spring vegetables and farro rissoto: Fall-off the bone tender, perfectly seasoned, and I enjoyed the twist on the rissoto

Roasted sea scallops: Cooked to perfection, not too briny or rubbery, to go very well with the white truffle asparagus, not too overwhelmed by the rich truffle oil.

Duck and Foie Gras Ravioli: Delicious, but too decadent for my taste. They give you a huge portion, too, about 3 times the amount I actually was expecting, even for an entree. Filling, with a good salty bite. Finishing this was the death of me, but a very enjoyable self-indulgent death.

Spaghetti: I love when simple, basic dishes are just beautifully executed. This was just the perfect spaghetti. I would be perfectly okay walking into a restaurant like this and ordering it. It is divine.

Mediterranean Branzino: Seafood party in my mouth. Branzino had a nice caramelized crust and the medley of vegetables and shrimp/clams/etc paired really well with the light broth.

Aged Sirloin of Beef: cooked to bloody medium-rare excellence. Enjoyed the salty/nutty bite of Parmagiano.

As for cocktails, I can recommend the Gimlet and the Gallardo.

What a giant disappointment. We saved Scarpetta for our final night in Vegas because it was my first choice of a new place to try. We won't ever return.

We had reservations at 6:30. We arrived at 6:24. I know this because the hostess pointed to the clock and noted that she would seat us in 6 minutes, since our reservation was for 6:30 pm. They were not busy -- no one else was waiting to be seated and only two people were sitting at the bar. We had to ask twice to check a coat, even though they have a clearly marked coat check.

At this point, we just figured the hostess was inexperienced or having a rough day. Once we were seated, we were promptly greeted and placed our cocktail orders. Our drinks took almost 20 minutes to arrive -- although we could see there were fewer than 20 people in the entire restaurant and there were at least 5 servers standing around chatting. The rest of the night, the service remained scattered, at best. We were rushed through our first course, but had to flag down the server to order dessert. 

On top of this, the server was constantly pushing us to "upgrade," after telling us that most of the plates, as is, are pretty minimal and that most people end up having to add to them with a second round of orders. For example, I ordered the fritto misto salad, which runs $18. The server warned me I should order a second primi, as well. He wasn't kidding -- I got two bites of greens with a dusting of lemon and seasoning. In short, the portions are small even for an upscale, trendy restaurant.

This place has one saving grace: the tomato and basil spaghetti. I admit I'm pretty picky about Italian food after I lived in Italy for a summer. I understand that it's rarely as good in the States. Although it's not as good as you'd get in Italy, the tomato and basil spaghetti is done well here. It has a nice light sauce (it's not arrabbiata -- it's a pureed sauce), and the pasta was cooked perfectly al dente.

I had the strawberry souffle for dessert. It was adequate, although it was fairly cool by the time they got it to the table. The coffee was fine, but the server forgot the extra shot of Frangelico I requested.

On the plus side, it's really beautiful. If you can get a seat in the windows, they overlook the Bellagio fountains (unfortunately, the window seats also overlook the Bellagio gardening sheds and dumpsters...so don't look down!). Overall, the decor fits in well with the contemporary vibe at the Cosmo. It's urban, beautifully designed, and hip. It's fresh, upscale, and open without being fussy or stuffy.

As beautiful as it is and as great as that pasta plate was -- I won't be back.

The view and ambience says it all. 
The impeccable service to exceed expectations of a nice, memorable, romantic dinner is absolutely the best. 
The dessert menu definitely gives that amusingly delightful smile after the initial to the final bite of soothing silky smoothness of that caramel sea salt dreamy pudding. Then the pastry chef's delectable dessert of the night... Absurdly decadent. 
This establishment is a "must revisit," type of place.

My favorite restaurant in Vegas, and my dear friend treated me as farewell meal. Even though I'm leaving Vegas, when I visit I will always return here. This is my 7th time here and I always try something new. This time it was the pasta with octopus and bone marrow,  topped with very delicious bread crumbs! The name of the dish was Gargnelli or something like that, regardless it was exquisite! My friend and I shared the polenta, because even if you come here 100 times you MUST have the polenta with fricasse mushrooms!  That is in my top 5 list for sure, but tonight something was not spot on I must admit, but I still enjoyed it. If you like cocktails the San Remo is the bomb. I have learned to make them at home because I enjoy so much! Luis our server deserves a huge shout out because he was wonderful.  This is another fabulous part of Scarpetta HOSPITALITY is A+++ all other places should send their staff here to learn from the best! I sincerely enjoy this restaurant and have turned many others on to it and they would agree :-)

Owner Scott Conant should be ashamed!!

We, my wife and I, arrived and were seating at a nice window table per our request. 
After that, its ALL DOWNHILL.

Server, some jackass who really could care less about being professional and more concerned about the table of 3 girls a few table away giving them free food all night.
He finally arrived at our table about 5 minutes after being seated, took our cocktail orders and then....disappeared.
He came back with our drinks 15 minutes later and blamed the "bartenders were backup up". Really? Because our martinis were warm when you served us which were very ordinary and especially at $15 per.

Busboy brought us bread which only one type was decent so we just asked for that only instead. Waiter "I will make sure to get that out to you immediately" That never happened.

Food: 
Heirloom tomato with Burrata- meh! I know its very simple and the wife wanted it but was as if Olive Garden made it. Really nothing special and was not seasoned properly.

Polenta with morels- again meh! Average at best.

Spaghetti what he is known for- very good not great. Would I order that again, no.

Halibut- dry! 

This place is a joke and we got duped! 

Pedestrian Food, Awful Service, High Prices = Avoid!
Started off with the squid & octopus appetizer, followed by the duck & foie gras ravioli, which were both delicious.

This is a late review as I've been really lazy but I'm trying to catch up! I came here with my boyfriend in November 2013 for this birthday and had the tasting menu. It was nothing short of amazinnng!  I will warn you, the portions are large for a tasting menu and you will get full! Ladies don't make the mistake of wearing a tight dress like I did! I was iffy about the tasting menu because I normally wouldn't choose to order most of what was on it and my boyfriend isn't a huge seafood person but we were feeling adventurous and wow were we surprised. The items I remembered the most were the raw yellowtail, fennel dusted black cod, spaghetti, and the desserts! Who knew simple spaghetti could be soo good! They were also sooo nice to give us three extra items on top of the tasting menu! Oh and also, their bread basket is the best I've had. Stromboli bread. Oh my goodness, I have dreams about this bread haha. The  ambience is very romantic and dimmly lit yet didn't feel stuffy or stiff like some higher end restaurants. I wish I took pictures but since our table was in the middle of two others tables I didn't want to disturb anyone with the flash of my camera. Oh and the view is really pretty! I hope to be back soon!!!

Party of 10. Ordered entrees, no appetizers & the service felt forever! There was no friendly gesture of the long wait or even up sale on appetizers or drinks. Don't get me wrong though food was amazing.

Went here for our anniversary which I booked reservations in advance.  We arrived at 6:35 and by 8:00 didn't have our main courses served.  Multiple other tables, whom arrived either when we did or after, had their meals consumed before we got ours. We orders three appetizers and only two showed up.  

When the meal did show up, the Lamb Chops (no idea why they called them chops when they were rack of lamb) were BLUE!  They took them back to the kitchen and while two people in the party continued to eat their meal (while they were still close to warm because they showed up already on the cold side).  The lamb came back and was now over cooked!   Even the ends/bone that is exposed were black/burnt.   By this time I ate was presented only because I was starving. 

The real question here is why two stars.  Correction, why one star because originally was going to give two but I cannot in good conscience give more than one.  One is for bring your own wine.  

Needless to say, we will never go back.

When I die, my heaven will include a daily dining experience at Scarpetta.  My boyfriend and I absolutely loved every minute.  When I come back to Vegas, I will be returning to this restaurant and having the exact same meal.  The scallop appetizer was perfectly paired with the foie gras; the beets and burrata appetizer had elements of sweet, savory, and sour (provided by the vinegarette).  But my favorite part of the meal was the simple, fresh spaghetti.  So divine.  The fresh ingredients and pasta sings in every bite.  I would eat this for breakfast lunch and dinner if I could.  Panna Cotta and Bananas Foster souffle to finish.  We left stuffed and happy.  Ready to take on Vegas!!  There is a gorgeous side view of the Bellagio fountains.  However, there is a large bar that extends the entire window so it perfectly blocks your view if you sit beside the window.  Why the designer would not just put floor to ceiling windows, thereby providing an uninterrupted view is beyond me.

A very nice alternative if you want a break from the Vegas buffets!  The creamy polenta with truffled mushrooms was amazing.  Had the duck and foie gras ravioli and it was equally as amazing....a bit rich but not overly rich where you felt sick after.  Was able to polish off the entire dish with no problem - and the portion was pretty generous considering you're at a high-end restaurant.  Normally at great Italian places they tend to skimp on the portions but they didn't.  My mom had the black cod and that was tasty as well.....but since their pasta is fresh I would recommend trying one of their pastas.  Bread basket was great, they have this salami bread that was awesome!  

Definitely have to try the one in Beverly Hills now!

My girlfriends brought me here for my bachelorette dinner. Our server Titus was awesome and they had a pretty decent wine list.

The food fell a little flat for me. 

The complimentary bread basket was phenomenal. My favorite was the focaccia with prosciutto.  Bread came with three different spreads: whipped butter mascarpone, eggplant caponata and a lemon infused olive oil.  Thy were all delicious but I especially enjoyed the eggplant caponata.

I ordered the Wagyu beef tartare as my appetizer. The beef wasn't as red as I would've liked it to be. It looked brown but I couldn't tell if it was from the bad lighting of the restaurant. The dish had no flavor and I basically had to force myself to eat it.

I ordered the duck and foie gras ravioli with a marsala reduction for my entree. I like that they make their own fresh pasta but the dish lacked the debt of flavor you'd expect from the components of this dish. It was like waiting for a climax that never came.

My friend really enjoyed her pea soup but the other girls didn't really rave about their dishes. 

The desserts (I forgot which ones we ordered) were great! We all definitely enjoyed that. 

The restaurant's decor is okay. It's somewhere between modern and classic. The lighting is really bad... Or good if you like it on the darker side. I like being able to see my food when I eat.

Server was knowledgeable and polite. Seated in the corner by the window over looking the water show. Amazing. Spaghetti is a small portion, but delicious and filling. Meatballs are very tiny like pellets. I loved it. Oysters were delicious with the Champagne. Great place for a date. My date really enjoyed it.

Dangit this place is good. 

We made a reservation because they were packed on a Friday night. It was last minute so we couldn't eat until 8. We were ready for some food! We both ordered the gnocchi with bacon and truffle oil. 

Sadly our order got lost after it was taken to the kitchen  and we ended up waiting 40 minutes for food. But the whole time, the waitress was so nice and apologetic and I could tell the kitchen was really embarrassed. When the meal came it was divine. That's the only way to put it. I had died and gone to heaven. 

Because of the mix up they offered us some yummy desserts on the house. The cheese cake was great! I was expecting more dessert options and it was weird that the waitress was kind of complaining about how only some of the desserts are tasty. But whatever. Free dessert!

At the end even with the free dessert the bill was a little high for us lower class folks but Dangit if we won't be back because the food was insane and the service was friendly.

If you like real italian food, give this place a try!

Unreal spaghetti. I know, it's spaghetti you say. Easy enough. It's amazing. Saw it on the Techniques episode of No Reservations, tried it, then had to punch myself for not trying it sooner in NY. Everything else was great too. Yellowtail and fritto misto to start, spaghetti and black cod to finish. Highlight was the spaghetti though.

Service was just what you would hope for in a restaurant of this caliber. Attentive to every need, but never in your space. 

We started with the octopus and squid salad. A fantastic choice. It was served some clover, chick peas, and a slice of octopus that was so tender, I couldn't believe it! The squid was rolled up plated with some greens as well. It was delish!

The pasta we chose was the house speciality - tomato and basil. It was so fresh and so basil-y! There was just something about it - almost creamy, but not creamy. The texture was all to do with the tossing of the pasta and sauce with a little EVOO as a second step. Yeah, I asked. 

For dinner I chose the veal chop, and I'm so glad that I did. It was cooked perfectly and was just the right size portion. My husband had the fennel crusted cod. It is prepared with the skin on, and was very nice (so he says, because I didn't get a taste!). 

Then dessert was a spectacle to behold. The anniversary trio was complete with chocolate-filled doughnuts, strawberry milkshakes, chocolate toffee brittle, and ice cream, too. It was unbelievable. 

We will definitely make this a regular stop in the LV book!

Scarpetta was very good, I am pretty mad that I did not order the duck ravioli though.

We brought a bottle of nice vino, and corkage was $35. Steep compared to Jaleo which only charged us $25. 

The pasta was amazing, very doughy and fresh. Apparently they make it hand-made every day, crazy. I had the Pici Lobster which was good but needed more sauce on it.

The heirloom tomato salad was great, but it came with a massive amount of cheese. So it was very rich and filling so be prepared to eat a lot of good cheese.

Skipped dessert, two people was around $200.

I took my wife here for her 40th Birthday and they knew we were coming and the reason. 

This was our first time here. We arrived minutes after 9PM.

The restaurant was dimly lit. The atmosphere was LOUD. Nothing romantic about this setting at all. 

HOSTESS

Her greeting was like listening to an answering machine. We had a 9:30 reservation (90 min before closing) and got sat in front of a pillar. I could not see the Bellagio fountains that seems to influence everybody's reviews. About 20 min later, 2 tables opened up that were right against the glass. In my reservation I let them know it was a special occasion. 

SERVER

Like the hostess, it was like watching blue man group after 3 straight performances. 

Just going through the motions. 

We were not interested in cocktails or wine, but were focused on some great cuisine. The server did stop once to go over the menu, but all he did was say "these are the apps, these are the pastas, these are the main courses" etc. etc. They must get a lot of people who never viewed a menu before. 

We ordered the Misto fritto, Farmers salad, Fennel Black Cod, and wrapped Veal loin. (I did not take any pictures this time, I did not want my review to be a distraction of the occasion) 

FOOD

My wife loved the complimentary bread which included dippers of olive oil, roasted eggplant and tomatoes, and truffle butter. The bread was varieties of an Italian Sourdough, foccacia, stromboli, and a vegetable stromboli. 

They automatically split our app & salad which I appreciated. 

MISTO FRITTO

The menu description was very vague, but I figured it had to be a spin off of fried calamari. Tempura battered squid, white anchovies, cauliflower, and the stems of chives. There were no anchovies in my plate, and happened to be my wife's first bite on her's which she did not like at all. I would not have known about the anchovies (which I love) if I did not finish her plate. The fry was perfect, and I really liked the seasoning which included rosemary. 

FARMERS SALAD

The presentation was beautiful. Some of the vegetables (green & yellow squash) were almost shaved. It was a nice salad, but not much flavor. There were only 2 choices of salad on the menu and I chose this one. My wife ate only half of hers. 

VEAL LOIN

There is a picture of this dish in the archives. 3 (2oz?) wrapped pieces of veal perfectly cooked. A few pieces of carrots and another vegetable. I tasted some sort of mustard on this dish with another sauce. The menu (again) was VERY vague. As I ate, I was wondering what the expense was in making this dish that carried a $38 price. 


BLACK COD

Presentation was standard, Looked to be about a 5oz filet. My wife was half way through her dish without a sound. Knowing my wife, this means she did not want to disappoint me in saying she did not care for it. I tried a bite and thought it was weird for Cod to be so mushy. It was not pleasant at all. Maybe even undercooked. 
My wife at all the vegetables and there was half of the filet sitting alone on the plate when the busser took it away. Sad that no one noticed that half of what was supposed to be the hero of this dish was being tossed out like a used tissue. 

We passed on dessert because to me, dessert should be the perfect finish to a perfect meal which this whole experience was not. My wife liked the complimentary bread the best and I liked the Fritto Misto the best. There was some woman in a very loud group making noises that reminded me of farm animals in heat. 

It shouldn't be this way in a restaurant of this price point.   

I asked for the check (1app, 1 salad, 2 entrees) $116.00 

As we were getting up to leave, a person came by with a dish that said happy birthday and had 2 biscotti"s , a cookie, a salted chocolate thingy and a lit candle.

Would have went better with a cappuccino but the check was already paid. 

This was a disappointing experience, even more so because I wanted it to be special for my wife's 40th. She liked the complimentary bread.....

If I can say something positive and relative, I would recommend going to D.O.C G. instead. Same Chef, different menu. Been there 5 times and loved it.

Staff are really nice! Ordered beef carpaccio w/ truffles, veal, mushrooms, some pasta etc...

Once we got the food we just had a little taste of everything then just took everything for take out. 

I definitely did not like the mushroom. Beef carpaccio w/ truffles is the only thing I liked w/ what we ordered. Spent more than $300 for something we didn't like :(

We liked the complimentary bread more than our actual dinner.

I ate at Scarpettas with two of my friends.   I would have given it a 4, but the service was poor.  You go to a place like this expecting excellent service.   I think our server took our order and dropped the bill off and that was about it.  The poor bus boy was stuck answering our questions,  taking drink orders.  He had to run and ask a server for some answers.   The food was good, just there is so many choices in Vegas.

This will become one of my go-to Vegas restaurants! I read the reviews on the spaghetti and yes, it's probably the most unassuming this on the menu, but for sure the BEST spaghetti I've ever had!! It would be hard for me to order anything else on the menu, yet there are so many more things I want to try. And dessert. Get dessert. The Nutella and vanilla italian donuts were amazing. I could have eaten a plate of those for dinner.
They have a very extensive wine list, but it is all pretty pricey for a bottle. A bottle of Oyster Bay Pinot Noir was $84. I don't mind paying for a good wine but Oyster Bay is far from worth $84. However, we did find a nice bottle for $115. But their wine list ranged from $84 to about $8000. So there is something for almost everyone.

This restaurant is amazing. Great food the portions are a little small. I would not recommend getting a salad because the menu has many so many other options. I did get the New York  steak and it was a good size portion. Great meal and good wine. Overall the experience the friendly staff really get a five star.

I dined at Scarpetta this past Saturday night.  We arrived 20 minutes early for our reservation and were seated right away.  I loved the atmosphere. Quiet with smooth hits from the 80s playing in the backround. 

The service was great and our server was very knowledgeable about the food and wine.  He recommended a great wine based on our specifications.

I tend to judge a restaurant by their breadbasket and Scarpetta gets an A+++. Skip the Italian bread they put on top of the basket and get to the cheese and pepperoni Stromboli.  I could have left happy after that.. it was amazing! The bread comes with olive oil, whipped marscapone and a tomato type sauce. 

We started with the Scallops and beet salad.  Both were excellent.  The Scallops ( 2 good sized scallops) were cooked perfectly.  The beet salad was nothing super fancy but I knew that when I ordered it.

My parents both opted for meatier entrees- Dad the veal chop and mom the NY strip.  My moms meat was slightly undercooked but she opted not to send it back to be cooked more.. Both were excellent.  I had heard so much about the Spaghetti that I decided to try that.  It was the best spaghetti I had ever had so it is definitely worth trying if you want a pasta dish.

For dessert we go the chocolate molten cake and it was the best Id ever had! The salted caramel sauce was a nice touch.  

I'd definitely go back to Scarpetta.  I liked it better than the other Italian options I've tried in Vegas (B&B, Carnevino).

This place is the best. We love this place so much, we always come here when in Vegas. We actually came two days in a row this time. The spaghetti is to die for and the braised short ribs appetizer is great. You can skip dessert here, not their strong suit, but the food is killer.

Excellent suggested Irish whiskey 
Beef cheek ravioli was fantastic.
Service was also very, very good.

Located in the Cosmopolitan, Scarpetta is a romantic Italian spot that came highly recommended to us from friends.  We were able to get an early reservation the day of for a party of two and there were several tables open when we arrived so you might be fine just walking in.  

The som helped us with a delicious bottle of wine in our price range.  To start we had the braised short rib with risotto cake and veggies.  It was a huge let down to start the meal. Think chicken pot pie down to the peas, carrots and corn. It did not match the vibe of the menu or ambiance at all and I would not recommend this dish.  I would, however, highly recommend everything else we ordered. The tagliatelle bolognese was rich and filling. The true star was the spaghetti though. I could not get over how dynamic and flavorful it was! So delicious and famous for good reason! Get this dish no matter what! And I can't pass up a dessert with amaretto in it so we split the chocolate cake with amaretto ice cream and drifted out of there blissfully content.

::Updated Review::

I came back to Scarpetta because I had such a wonderful experience when I first ate here.  Unfortunately, my recent visit was not as great.  Although, the ambiance is still nice and classy. 

::Drinks::
The Berry Smash was a hit but when I got it again, the flavor was different.  The alcohol was strong which was good but the drink was not as fruity.

::Food::
I got the Lardo Wrapped Prawns before and I liked it, but on this visit it was too salty.  The Prime Filet of Beef was tender but there was no "wow" factor.  My highlight of the night is still the Short Rib and Bone Marrow Agnolotti; it's so good!!

::Dessert::
I picked the Nutella and Vanilla Creme Bomboloni.  It was warm and fresh but nothing special.  

::Customer Service::
The customer service was superb on my first visit.  The second time around, surprisingly it was not the same.  I was a bit disappointed.

::Tips::
-Try the Short Rib and Bone Marrow Agnolotti!
-Request to sit by the window so you can watch the Bellagio Fountain Show. 
-Please read my first review for more information or if you are curious about my first visit.

Scott Conant would have "Chopped" his own restaurant last night!!  Dinner with 11 friends, reservation made weeks ago. We were seated in a location that the staff had to continually pass things over one person to another as they wasn't enough room to walk around the table to serve each person.  The apps came out in a scattered pattern and the hot ones were anything but hot!  We even had to send one back as it was downright cold.  The entrees were marginally better. They arrived with in minutes of each other! And of course they had to get one wrong!! Which took almost 15 minutes to get right and out to our table! The $50+ steak, that was recommended and ordered medium rare came out medium well.  The veal chop that I ordered medium rare came out medium and obviously had been sitting on the pass line as it was room temperature at best.  When we explained the continuos problems to the Manager/sommelier he response was these things happen. Well these people will not happen to be going back to Scarpetta.  In a town with hundreds of choices that go out of their way to make your dining experience enjoyable, this one should be Chopped off your list!

Have I known that this place was known for its spaghetti then I would have gotten it. I just can't see paying $15-25 for spaghetti. 

But the atmosphere of this restaurant is hip & modern-like the hotel itself. Our waiter was super friendly and gave us great service as well as the bussers and host. I ordered the blackened cod and my BF ordered the veal, ick..I don't know what veal is supposed to taste like since I haven't had it before but I tasted it and didn't like it. But my blackened cod was really good and we ordered the seared yellow tail for an appe-teaser! OMG, it was the best I have ever tasted, I highly recommend this! It had a lemon nutty flavor that just melt in my mouth! So good!! 

And they give you bread before your meal, yummy, they had different varieties that you can choose from and trust me all of them are good! 

Definitely would go back but going to try the spaghetti next time..

I been to the Scarpetta in Beverly Hills, was a bit disappointed in the food there but decided to give this one a try.

GOOD CHOICE! I loved the venue, on the 3rd floor of the Cosmo, mid dark light very elegant, though it is a bit more crowded due to the small space, but the bar area is very cute.

We got 4 diff appetizers, beet salad, pork belly, scallops and Beef I liked them all

Then 4 entrees: black cod, foie gras ravioli, diff meats ravioli and i forgot the last one! but again it was delicious, the black cod melts in your mouth!

Different we got an apple pie sort with ice cream and raspberries.

Def coming out here again next time  invegas. Cosmo is just beautiful and elegant hotel very modern, but trying STK next time

I had dinner here the other night and went in with moderate expectations and closed the evening happy, and smiling from ear to ear. 


Atmosphere =  fantastic. We had a table for 2 with a view of the Bellagio Fountains. 

Service = excellent. The waiter was amazing and started us off with a delicious glass of wine.  My friend and I told him what kind of wine we liked; a heavy red. He brought an amazing glass that was delicious. I don't recall the name, but It was a blend from Santa Barbara and exactly what we wanted. 

Food = delicious. I couldn't make my mind up and asked the waiter for a suggestion between 3 pasta dishes I was considering. His suggestion was the Short Rib & Bone Marrow Agnolotti.  I've never had "bone marrow" anything, but I was willing to give it a try. I ate every piece and nearly licked the plate.  What I respected the most? The waiter wasn't trying to sell me on the most expensive dish. In fact, it was one of the less expensive pasta dishes to choose from! 

Desert = Heavenly & Sinful. I am not a "sweets / desert person,so I "passed" on ordering a desert. My friend ordered a desert that were like cream filled donuts. The waiter brought me out a tiny little spoon to "taste" the desert or was teasing me.  He ended up bringing me a full on desert spoon! Delicious! 

Not too expensive. Great ambiance, fantastic customer service and delicious food. I will def return and suggest Scarpetta. ;-))))

It was hard to give this place 2 stars as the food was DELICIOUS!  The location is awesome and we had a great table by the window.  The view is great.  The service was horrible.  They were having some computer problems.  It would have been great if the server came and explained that to us, instead he just disappeared and I guess was trying to fix it.  I am not a needy diner by any means, however, our wine glasses were empty for a while (which we spent $70 per glass for), we would have ordered dessert but it just took too long.  It was almost like we were forgotten.  Spending almost $300 for 2 people should get you AMAZING service.

My sister asked me to find a good place to have pre-Christmas dinner with our Mom in Las Vegas and I actually found Scarpetta by searching for top rated restaurants near the strip with foie gras. Seriously. I need my foie gras.

With the recent foie gras ban in California keeping me from one of my favorite delicacies, I definitely wanted to have it if I was crossing state lines.  Scarpetta stuck out to me because it wasn't a French restaurant, but an Italian one, which is my Mom's favorite... and a great way for everyone to be happy.

Scarpetta was perfect. Situated in the new and beautiful Cosmopolitan hotel, it has an amazing view of the Bellagio and definitely has that upscale "we are dining somewhere really fancy" vibe.  The server was really enthusiastic about the dishes and described them each eloquently (I read one person's review that found this annoying, but I thought it was great!) and helped with recommendations for what to order.

Starter:

POLENTA with Mushrooms. Oh. My God. To DIE FOR. Seriously.  Wow.  Best dish of the night and that's saying a lot because everything was great.

Mains:

Duck and Foie Gras Ravioli - Obviously what I ordered and obviously I loved it.  I was also pleasantly surprised by the portion size. Usually when you order ravioli you get like, 4, and are left being hungry, but not in this case. It was a generous portion.  I would have loved there to be more foie gras but that's just being greedy.

Fennel Spiced Black Cod - My mom ordered this and it was probably the least interesting thing that we had, but still delicious.

Black Tonarelli - My sister ordered this and it was also amazing, al dente, just as it should be.  It took about 10 minutes to come out after the rest of the dishes and they kept apologizing profusely for it and then sent out TWO free desserts to make up for it.

(FREE!) Desserts:

Mascarpone Cheesecake - lighter than your average cheesecake, which made me like it more.

Amaedi Chocolate Cake - like a lava cake, but better.. the perfect texture / consistency with hot melted chocolate inside... served with almond ice cream...

This was one of the best Italian meals I've ever had outside of Italy,  and I've tried all of those overrated high end Italian restaurants in Los Angeles. I was expecting much less, thinking this was a bit of a tourist trap that I was buying into for the evening. It ended up being so much more. I was so pleasantly surprised and happy with the experience. Also, no BS portion sizes.. these are hearty portions and you will leave full.

Definitely one of my top (if not the top) Italian restaurants outside Italy.  I just may need to go visit the Scarpetta in LA.

I came here just for desserts, so my review is based solely off of that. We actually came here twice just for dessert despite having other dessert places to check off on my 4 day trip to Vegas. We liked it that much. I am a huge huge coconut fan, give me anything coconut and I'll have to try it. With both their cheesecake and their panna cotta having that coconut element, I absolutely had to indulge. The panna cotta is absolutely divine, the base is coconut and it's layered with a "guava soup" - the dessert is totally an experience. Now the cheesecake, the cheesecake was just unforgettable we loved the mango sorbet that accompanied the cheesecake to counter the sweetness, it was the perfectly balanced dessert - needless to say we devoured the whole thing.

Bravo to scarpetta for an excellent dinner this past weekend.  We were lucky enough to sit at the "chef's table" and we had a clear view of the kitchen at work.  We even heard the chef shout out orders like hell's kitchen: One risotto, two spaghettis; we had a party of 9 for a birthday and they treated us like kings.  The waiter Titus was an amazing help and made the meal excellent.  The food that was prepared was spot on! I had the world-renowned plate of goodness known as the spaghetti, but let me tell you this is not your typical pasta dish.  The pasta was cooked perfectly al dente and the infusion of fresh tomato and basil all concentrated into the smooth pasta was a burst of flavor in my mouth.  For my appetizer i had the polenta that "has been stewing in the kitchen prepared by grandma for three hours." It was amazing; the best polenta i have had topped off with a truffle sauce mixture with mushrooms.  For dessert, I recommend the panna cotta, like i say a great panna cotta's consistency should jiggle like a nice woman's bosom and this dish jiggled perfectly.  The melt in your mouth dessert with a hint of coconut was a perfect end to a grand evening.  GO here and try it over and over again because the spaghetti is addictive.

Authentic Italian food and house made pasta--the only way to enjoy Italian food. Scarpetta was a lovely experience. The duck foie gras ravioli was great but the stand out was definitely the spaghetti--cooked to perfection. The orata (branzino) was nicely done, too. While I'd pass on the chocolate cake which tasted a bit generic, my favorite of the night was the pana cotta--delicious! The service was decent--slightly snobby but it comes with the territory. I'd love to dine here again.

My husband and I could not wait to dine at Scarpetta in Las Vegas after having a perfect evening at the Scarpetta Miami months prior. Unfortunately the service at this location is so disappointing.  Our greeting was frazzled and rushed, our seat was lovely looking at the fountains nice and private. Our server from first greeting had an awful attitude-rather snotty really and never shared his name. Our food was absolutely perfect but our overall experience was ruined by lack of service here. I specifically said I would like wine with my dinner as my last experience in Miami was heightened by the perfectly selected glass of wine by the charming sommelier.  Here our glasses were left empty our entire meal!  My husband had finished his cocktail before the appetizer!  When dinner arrived we were over half finished before our server asked if everything was fine.  Clearly this was disappointing which then caused us to decide to not have another drink nor coffee and dessert as we had hoped.  When we asked for the check the server asked if there was something wrong which was frustrating and we chose to not bother as it seemed that could be confrontational. 
Again, our food was perfect it was just a completely different feel than expected-one I would not want to repeat.

Went in on Sat night and felt like I was in Rome the food was that good.  Wow!  Tremendous experience.  The service is probably the best we've had in Vegas, they're that talented.  And the pasta is really that good!  I strongly recommend it here.  Mario the GM came over to see how our meal was which shows how caring their team is.   I noticed as walking out they have a really nice private dinning room for special partys that faces the water show at Belligiao...

Fine dining at it's finest!

Came here a Saturday night during my last trip to Vegas for a bachelorette party (apparently we weren't the only ones) and we were seated right in the middle on a long table which was nice for a party of 7 girls. Our waiter and busers were on point and our waiter was really nice and always conversated with us and made our experience fab!

Let's talk about that bread basket...how crazy is it that they actually have salami in one of the breads. They also have sourdough and herb focaccia  . They have butter, olive oil and this roasted tomato eggplant as a spread to go with the variety of bread they give. I liked the herb focaccia bread the best with the butter...it was toasted and soft in a small square (good for portion size). For my meal I got the black cod with tomato's and fennel because I love butterfish and I only eat seafood and I love vegetables...although I was debating on getting this or the halibut, I'm glad I went with this because it was so divine! I wish the portion was bigger but it's one of those restaurants where it's quality over quantity. We ordered 2 whites and 1 bottle of reds that night, and because my stomach was not having it, I only drank a glass of the 1st bottle. Some of the girls ordered the lobster, scallop appetizers, split pea soup, foi Gras ravioli and steak and everyone said everything they ordered was great. For desserts we got the hazelnut mini donuts, strawberry cheesecake/shortcake in a cup dessert over a bed of crystallized sugar...I didn't get to try any of them but everything was all gone so it must've been delicious. 


Overall the ambiance is beautiful, food is amazing/drinks and bread, awesome service and fine dining at it's finest. The portions are a little small and the price is a little pricey but worth it especially when it's a special occasion like a birthday, anniversary, valentines day, mothers day or bachelorette dinner =)

I had wanted to dine at Scarpetta since I first laid eyes on Scott Conant via Chopped. The man is downright foxy. My favorite food happens to be pasta too, so clearly it was meant to be. 

Located in the swanky Cosmopolitan hotel, the first thing you see are cascades of chandeliers and purple backlights throughout the main floor. The restaurant itself is dimly lit with lots of stone and dark accents creating a chic yet inviting space. 

I suggest making reservations (we did so through Open Table) and also be sure to ask for a window table if available. Those have a clear view of the strip and Bellagio fountains. Sadly they were all taken the night we went, but they sat us as close as they could so we still had a nice view from our seats. 

They start your meal off with a complimentary bread basket, and we enjoyed the variety of it. There was sourdough, a rosemary focaccia, I believe a wheat of some kind, and two which were stuffed with goodness including pesto and cheese. Spread on some mascarpone butter or dunk in the citrus olive oil and it completely elevates it to another level. 

My husband couldn't help himself and ordered another after we devoured it. They obliged, but seemed surprised by the request. I'm guessing not many people ask for refills. We are carb people, what can we say? 

I knew ahead of time I would be ordering the $24 plate of tomato and basil spaghetti, and it was worth every penny. I'm almost certain I read he doesn't use cream in the sauce, but he sure fooled me because it was deliciously silky. When they set our plates down they removed a lid which had sealed in steam to keep the pasta fresh, and the aroma automatically made us salivate. It was the sexiest plate of pasta I had ever seen and tasted in my life. 

My husband opted for a vegetable pasta which came dressed in a luxurious truffle zabaglione. When it comes to Italian food he almost always picks a meat dish over pasta, but he ate every last bite. 

Our dinner was simply impeccable. My expectations were well exceeded and I cannot wait to make a return visit. The staff are wonderfully hospitable and helped make our evening that much more enjoyable.

I was in Vegas over the 4th of July weekend with some friends and family. We decided to give Scarpetta a try since it sounded nice and was close to our hotel. The restaurant is beautiful and the wait staff was great (very friendly, polite and professional). The view from the restaurant is on the Bellagio fountains, which was very nice (you actually get a nice panoramic view of part of the strip). As for the food, I was pleasantly surpised. I had the duck foie gras ravioli and it was quite nice. My girlfriend had the Pici pasta which was absolutely amazing! If you are in Vegas and looking to have a nice dinner I would say head over to Scarpetta.

Recently had dinner here. Reservation at 7:30, seated at 8:10. Staff unapologetic. Limited choice, small portions, food mediocre,expensive.
The room was so dark, we needed a flashlight to read the menu. I definitely will not return.

I had heard about Scarpetta multiple times on Travel Channel (Anthony Bourdain) and Food Network (Best Thing I ever Ate).  Scott Conant is also a celebrity chef that is on some Food Network shows.  I happened to be at a conference at the Cosmopolitan (my new favorite hotel in Vegas, BTW), and I figured I might as well stop by and try out the food at Scarpetta.

The inside of the restaurant has a good view of the faux lake at the Bellagio.  Big windows and a nice decor are the first thing you notice.  The food is what we were really there for, so I was excited about that.  For appetizer, we ordered duck and foie gras ravioli's with a wine reduction sauce.  This was just amazing....heavy and rich, but it is foie gras, so you should expect that.  Since it was a regular menu item and not an appetizer, they split it in half for my co-worker and I.

Upon receiving the raviolis, our server (who was very good....attentive and knowledgable) brought over a basket of 3 breads.  One was ciabatta, one was a focaccia (or something similar) with pork (prosciutto, maybe?) and cheese rolled into it.  I can't remember the third bread, but it was also good.

Next up was the main meal.  I ordered the spaghetti (with tomato and basil), and my co-worker ordered the branzino.
