The spaghetti is what I had seen featured multiple times on TV, and I am always a skeptic.  I didn't think it could possibly be the best spaghetti I had ever had, but I was wrong.  This spaghetti was the absolute best I have ever had.  There was so much flavor concentrated on FRESH pasta.  Every bite was heaven, and for $24, I would order it again for sure.  Vegas (and NY) are both expensive for nice restaurants, so the price tag is high compared to your local favorite Italian place, but the pasta just isn't the same.

My co-workers branzino was also excellent.  Served with some greens and onion, it was cooked perfectly (crispy skin), and the flavor was very fresh.  

I can't say enough about this restaurant.  I highly recommend anyone going to the Cosmopolitan check this place out.  Definitely one of my better dining experiences for Italian food.

Worst experience ever. Our waiter was a pompous jerk who came back to our table twice until our bill was due and then he was back every two minutes even though our wine wasn't finished. The manager came to the two tables next to us and offered free wine and said nothing to us. Very disappointing considering we are huge Scott fans.

We were in Vegas last weekend for a birthday, and as Chopped fans we had to go. We spent the week prior drooling over the menu but that didn't help, we were still having a hard time choosing what to order. So many great options!

I went with the Pici while the bf went with the Prime Fillet. The Pici was spicy and unbelievably delicious. The Fillet was tender and probably the best piece of meat I've ever put in my mouth. 

Scarpetta has ruined Italian food for me. Pasta is freshly handmade. I'm getting an Imperia and never eating pasta out of a box again.

Scarpetta fits well in the sophisticated Cosmopolitan Hotel. Tucked away into a corner, this restaurant is unassuming at first approach. The lights are dim and there are curvy booths on the right side facing a long bar. The walkway is narrow but keep the eye on the prize at the end because that's where the true "meat" of the restaurant is. Tables and booths are snugly placed in a modern yet cozy dining area. For our group of 10, the broad shouldered guys probably felt a little too close for comfort to make room for all of us to fit, but it wasn't a problem for the girls. 

Last Saturday, we were in a mad rush to eat and run because we were trying to catch a 9:30pm showing of KA at MGM. Our dinner reservation was 7:30pm so we cut it close. We asked the waiter to divide our check between 5 couples and to make things worse, we did not sit next to our significant others. We brushed off the sommelier by accident because we wanted to find our waiter just to order right away. In spite of our group being a nightmare, they made our plans happen and with time to boot! The food was amazing, our checks were split perfectly, and the waiter even offered detailed directions how to get to our show quicker. 

The duck fois gras ravioli and the short rib agnolotti were the two dishes my husband and I shared. We loved these dishes. The guys in our group ordered steaks which were all well prepared and the girls ordered appetizers and a couple dishes to share but I think Bry and I were the happiest out of the group with our choices, which is surprising because I always choose steak over anything. 

Looking back, I feel bad that we put the staff in a position where everything needed to be rushed but overall, our entire group was impressed with the food and service. Thanks Scarpetta for that!

This place left such an impact that I almost went back to my room to write a Yelp! OMG I just finished writing and realize no one in their right mind will ever read this- it's an essay!

Just got back from an impromptu b-day trip from Las Vegas. Had an amazing time w the guy and the memorable meal of the trip was a b-day dinner at Scarpetta- great recommendation from a friend.

Everything here is phenomenal but I want to start w the service. Mathew our server,  was cordial, friendly & extremely informative. The table next door said he was Captain Morgan come to life but he reminded us of a younger refined Gary Oldman mixed w someone else. :)

One thing I really appreciate in any server is someone that shares their experiences w various dishes and points you in the direction you want to go. We filled him in on the 3 dishes we knew we wanted and he put real thought into helping us choose the final dish. Not only that, he was exceptionally personable; and we had great small talk- always love that.

Alright to the review and apologize in advance for the blabbering!

To Start: 
An unassuming covered basket of bread is left on the table. On the outside is an inconspicuous piece of sliced sourdough on top... nothing special right?
I'm thinking "PASS trying to cut carbs!"
Surprise!!! 2 types of STROMBOLI (I believe it was Pesto/Cheese and Salami or a Tasso Ham and Cheese) and fresh rosemary cibatta inside. Proceed to annihilate entire basket.

We ended up sharing everything we ordered so they portioned out everything for us, it was perfect and presentation was beautiful. 

Starters:
Vancouver Island Oysters: Fresh Oysters, enough said.

Dungeness Crab and White Corn Soup: My rule of thumb is to always order soup if it's on the menu and isn't a house soup. I've been unsuccessful in making a solid corn soup, leave it to the professionals I say! This was the perfect, hot, super creamy, flavor filled soup I wish to one day master. The corn scent wafted into your nose as the base was poured over the  chunks of crab, table side. I definitely conjured Toucan Sam (corn soup version) for a second.

Pici: (pronounced peachy like the folders) 
Homemade pasta sort of like a thicker fettuccine noodle on steroids. Parsley and other goodies are blended in the flour which adds a green hue and extra umph. It comes w lobster and a taragon, almond and chili pesto. I'm not a huge pesto fan but luckily for me it's not a traditional pesto; it's not even a sauce. They give you the perfect amount to coat but not over power the dish and it has a serious kick. Very generous portion of lobster, and a staple at the restaurant. MUST TRY IT.

KOBE BEEF RIB CAP: This was $68, on our last trip to Vegas we had the Japanese Waygu at Cut which I think has permanently changed my views on the price of steak.
This was 7 oz and extremely rich, barely needed a knife, and it just melted in your mouth. It came w potato gnocchi, wild mushrooms & a reduction that is seriously making my mouth water in retrospect.

Peach Costata: Salted Shortbread covered w Cardamon ice cream and chunks of peach. It was a spicy dessert (take note if that's not your thing) that complimented our decaf cappuccino's! The decaf cap's were suggested by Mathew when we originally ordered just decaf coffee. Great suggestion, paired perfect w the dessert.

Oh MAN 2 things I left out- 
I had a dirty martini w blue cheese filled olives; holy goodness; i hope i can order this at other places.

Lastly; we were here on the 4th of July; right when we were paying Mathew mentioned we could wait because the fireworks at Caesar's were starting in 10 minutes. They allowed us to stay and watch for 30+ mins (late start) even though the restaurant was filling up. I thought that was really nice of them (they didn't even know it was my bday!) haha and there was no rush to get us out the door.

Taking into account service, ambiance and quality I put this in my top 3 best dining experiences ever :) also you can  tell I loved the service considering I mentioned the server by name 3x in the post!? Foie Gras Ravioli, you're next!

Scott Conant's place in the Cosmo is really nice and the food is delicious. The service was first class, I felt like I was aboard the titanic, haha. The waiter knew his shit and helped me and my buddies pair our dishes perfectly with some wines, and we're not quite wine guys, but we all enjoyed it. The desert, chocolate cake, was so rich and delicious and the caramelized almond sorbet made it. Eat here and smile . Thanks place.
Nice atmosphere and very good view of Bellagio fountains.  Food was too salty the first time but very good the second time.

Made a reservation three weeks before dining here and requested a table with a view of the Bellagio fountain.  We came 15 minutes early and we're seated away from the window.   I noticed an open table next to the window and requested to be moved there.  The hostess informed us that the table was not ready and that it was already reserved.   Really?  Sure... Bad start to the evening. ..

Chef Dave was amazing!! The food was delicious! We went there for a bachelorette party and thanks to Bex for being able to get us seats at the chefs table! If you ever plan on going to vegas please ask for Bex!!

I might as well start with the one thing that the restaurant got right: service. Everything else was a disaster.

Let's start with the menu. I am still trying to figure out how they came up with this menu. Did they Google "fancy Italian menu"? Did they copy Olive Garden's and just add in some more fancy ingredients? One will never know. What I do know, however, is that a 44 ounce steak is probably not something one eats in Italy. I'm also pretty sure vegetable medley and dishes served with only a starch are not something I've ever seen in a fine dining establishment.

Now, let's move on to the food: the absolute worst part of the evening. I ordered the osso buco, which I'll understate as absolutely disgusting. The tomato sauce was sour, watery, and lacked any flavor or complexity whatsoever. The veal shank was dry and not seasoned at all. The polenta had no flavor and was covered in bland cheese. Had my server brought me Pizza Hut instead, it would have been an upgrade.

If somehow Cosmo could move the excellent servers to another one of their restaurants and then bulldoze the daylights out of the disaster that is Scarpetta, the world would be a better place. Save yourself the money and eat at the many restaurants in Las Vegas that are actually good.

After visiting Scarpetta in LA, I cannot wait to see what the Vegas one has to offer. They serve the same menu but the ambiance there is totally different. The Vegas one has a gorgeous view of Bellagio's fountain and the decor is more old, rustic and not as classy and glamorous as the LA one. The waiter here is very helpful and funny. 
 
The food here is delicious:

+ Beef Tartare: Cooked with lime juice so quite sour but refreshing. Very different from traditional beef tartare.
+ Raw Yellowtail: It's okay. Pretty typical, but I'm surprise how non-fatty the fish taste considering hamachi is a fattier fish.
+ The spaghetti: good as always--al dente with a sauce that's sweet with a hint of tang. 
+ Tagliatelle: A pasta with spring veggies. This tasted too green and peas-filled for me. The cream sauce also too thick. 
+ Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli: This was delicious but the foie gras taste is very mild. 
+ Mediterranean Branzino: The fish has a really, really nice sear on the outside and it was very soft and tasty. 

Don't skip dessert! Dessert was phenomenal! 

+ Strawberry Tart : The tart crust was amazing! It has that crunch and the cream was so light. The meringue that came with the dessert didn't taste like basil as described, but it was still really good. 

+and the Nutella & Vanilla Creme Bomboloni: Reminds me of hot bigne with creamy nutty chocolate center! It's so good. And I have no idea how they caramelized a banana. It has the crunch and then creaminess of the fruit.

OHHH, Scarpetta, why do you have to be soooooo good? After this weekend and the amazing service we had from Travis. All I can do is dream about my dinner. WHATTT? You can order meatballs on your crack spaghetti? Hell yesss and if you think you loved the spitball than, wait till you have them with these tiny little meatballs. Now, I have a new addiction.. THE HALIBUT! WTH??? and the scallops! Talk about not eating much seafood, but Friday night I was seeing a lot of SEAFOOD and loving it! By the time I had a drink called the Smashing Blush and some other specialty drink with whiskey, yup, you heard me... WHISKEY, I guess I was blushing smashed. Overall, service and food was impeccable and the desserts, were enough for me to think about not taking the leftover few strands of spaghetti back to my hotel room. Now, THANK GOD I did, since after my Pitbull Concert and another cocktail from the show, I stumbled in my room hungry and hungover and cold spaghetti at 12:00 AM, was still delicious!

Very high priced, semi-Italian fusion type of food.

Some really good fish dishes, try the halibut from the meat menu.

Definitely gotta make a reservation in advance. 

if you're a party of 6 or more, request to be seated in their private room with a view of the Bellagio fountains water show.

Ate here last week when I went into Vegas for a concert. My friends truffle pasta was delish and hot. I got the Al Ceppo and it wasn't anything fabulous. My food actually came out barely room temperature. I don't think they had it sitting under the salamander considering my friends Truffle pasta was piping hot. I was told their entrees were small and I should order two meals or a salad so I did. The salad I ordered was pretty tasty. I do think it's all overpriced. Not worth the money spent although I heard their basil spaghetti was really good. The complimentary bread with salami was delish with the eggplant! Must say tastiest bread I've had in a long time.

This place was a total joke! We go out for dinner frequently and love to try new places.  We sat for over 15 minutes without even being acknowledged and finally left. No one even bothered to ask why we were leaving and staff were just standing around. What a waste of a good location in Inglewood! We then wandered down to The Ironwood to grab a drink and try to figure out where to go for dinner and had a great time! Amazing service, awesome staff. Highly recommend them. Don't even waste your time at 500 Cucina aka Scarpettas.

We had great seating next to the windows viewing the Bellagio fountains as requested.
The food was much better presented and tasteful than other Italian restaurants I've visited in LV.

The bread basket is delightful with the trio of accompaniments: marscapone butter, Eggplant in tomato ragu and citrus infused oil.  For appetizer we had the creamy polenta. Enough for one or two to share as it is extremely rich as a separate duo of perfectly creamed polenta and truffled mushrooms. If you haven't already gobbled up your breads, make useful tool to sweep up the last juices.
Three of us got the black cod which is superbly moist and light with a crisp skin, but the vegetables (fennel/peppers) were a bit too sour to match with.  And the other three got the duck foie gras ravioli which was rich and poignant with flavor but not unpleasant. The balsamic glaze was apparent and not overwhelming. I would have finished the entire plate.  

Why the three stars? LACK of consistent service :(
I don't include the guy who kept our water glasses filled. But we were all (party of 6) sourly disappointed with the main waiter. He only presented himself to take our order and serve the appetizer.  Didn't even refilled our breads as asked.  Then with empty plates, we all sat there for 15 minutes watching our server chummy up with a table of 3 girls and another table drinking it up with ample wine bottles. An assistant manager in a suit, bless him, came over, asked how our dinner was, saw our plates and decided to clear our table himself and also bring us our check.
Although we weren't completely dissatisfied with the whole dining experience, it's just unsettling when the server is MIA with you and present elsewhere. 
So, maybe next time. If there is a next time.

Great view, good food, we had family style, and we were a bit hurried, but the service was great, and the food was good, Im not sure I gave it a full run through, as we were headed out for the night, the service was good, its small and can feel a little crowded, but overall, id try it again.   I did NOT dig the Cosmopolitan Hotel, we went to my friends suite, and it was unimpressive, and the night club scene was for a bunch of wannabee 23 yr olds.

Modern decor, nice view looking over Bellagio'd fountain on the window side. 
Service was great, food was good but not that high as I expected. Daily special linguini was good but salty. If saltiness of this dish was perfect, it could be the best dish of the day. Signature tomato home made spaghetti , fresh pasta was great but again the tomato sauce was heavy because of butter I guess.  If you're looking for authentic Italian, this is not a place to go.

Picture four girls who have been drinking all day downstairs at the Marquee Day Club, starved out of their minds. Not really the way I imagined myself dining for the first time at the famous Scarpetta, but hey, at least I was ready to eat.

We crawled in in our flip flops and denim shorts right when the restaurant opened. The tables were already all booked (at 6pm!), but they have some nice booth seats by the bar. 

First off, the complimentary bread. My god. Warm and chewy, stuffed with sausage or spinach and cheese, with olive oil for dipping. We had to get a second round of this, it was so fantastic. 

We also shared four pastas:
- spaghetti (with tomato and basil, that's it!)
- duck & foie gras ravioli
- pici (with lobster, tarragon, almond & chili pesto)
- short rib & bone marrow agnolotti (the toasted breadcrumbs added such a fabulous texture and crunch!)

All the dishes were phenomenal, but the spaghetti was by far my favorite. Typically spaghetti doesn't do it for me, but now that I know what it's supposed to taste like, I've changed my mind. So simple, yet so delicious. It was cooked perfectly al dente, and so rich and full of flavor I didn't even miss the creaminess (or cheesiness) of other pastas. 

A MUST-VISIT IF YOU'RE EVER IN VEGAS!

There's no word that describes Scarpetta better than perfect. The decor is inviting, and cozy while still giving that "Las Vegas feel". 

The service was prompt and the food was excellent. Every dish we ordered was fresh and full of flavor. I ordered the short rib pasta which was absolutely delicious. 

I absolutely recommend to anyone looking for a memorable dinner in LV.

For our last night in Vegas, we were looking to splurge a bit for our dinner out. I got super excited when I learned this is one of Scott Conant's restaurants because I love Italian food and I see him on Chopped all the time.

The restaurant is located on the third floor, just take the escalators up near Marquee and Chandelier. I made reservations using open table for 10 pm (a bit late, but we just got drinks in Chandelier beforehand) and were seated shortly after 10 at a table near the windows. We could see the Bellagio and the watershow - very nice view.

First off, the bread basket and the toppings for it were so good! A butter marscapone, eggplant, and olive oil were provided to go with the different breads. There was a sourdough and some other types, but my favorite was this bread with mozzarella baked into it. And, I don't even like eggplant, but my favorite bread topping was the eggplant - it was that yummy.

Based on other reviews and what sounded good to us, my friend and I ordered the polenta to start, which was split into two separate dishes for us. Amazingly tasty. I have to say I haven't had polenta before, but I figured this would be a good place to try it, and boy was that a good decision. It was just so creamy with a little bit of a gritty texture, but mmmmm. I don't know how else to describe it.

For my entree I had the tagliatelle with vegetables, guanciale, and truffle zabaglione - housemade pasta! Another very mmmmmm dish. My tastebuds were happy. And for dessert, I had the coconut panna cotta with guava "soup". Perfect end to the meal since it was lighter, fresher, and sweet. 

All in all, I thought the food was great and I would consider coming back if I was splurging a bit. Only thing I didn't really care for was the bathroom. There was only one stall for women and it wasn't that great, and my friend said there was a line of about 6 women when she went. I would expect a nice restaurant to have a nicer bathroom.

Had dinner at Scarpetta a couple weeks ago with friends.  The ambiance of the place was nice. Service was excellent and the sommelier was great with his suggestions of wines.  Had a very nice refreshing wine from Cake Bread which went well with our meal.

I gave this place a 3 stars only because the food was ok.. it was good.. but not great.  Perhaps I was expecting it to be a bit better based on the previous reviews from other yelpers (ie. going in with too high expectations).  Don't get me wrong, it was a nice dinner.  Just not as great as what I anticipated it to be..

Don't think I would go back as there are plenty of other great restaurants in Vegas for italian.

Peace out..

The best view on the strip for a romantic dinner facing the Bellagio's water show.  The only minor detail that could have made it much better was the structural beam that went right across us at eye level.  Apparently the space was originally designed to be the kitchen and not the main dining room.

Anyway, the food, the meal, the experience.  We did the tasting menu which was AMAZING & EXPENSIVE but AMAZING!  To wrap it up in a nutshell we enjoyed duck, fish, scallop, shoe string calamari & zucchini, polenta with a mushroom broth, tomato basil spaghetti (famous on FoodTV), & decadent warm chocolate cake and delightful peach soupy thing for dessert. Yes!  All of that in one meal.  I almost needed a wheelchair just to get out of there.

Our server was so attentive and the wines that were paired with each dish was just perfect.  Heaven.  Enough said.

This is one of my favorite splurge dinner places in Vegas. My friend and I came here during our annual girls weekend. We are both big fans of eating out so we were very excited to come here. Our waiter was very attentive and we did not feel like we had to get his attention to order or get our check. One of the things I love about dining here is that they have one of the most extensive and delicious bread baskets ever (4 types of bread and 3 spread/dips). 

As for the food and drinks, we ordered a nice bottle of sauvignon blanc which was reasonably priced compared to their cocktail prices. We shared the polenta to start, which the restaurant kindly split between 2 bowls for us, which was a very nice gesture. For our entrées we shared the short rib agnolotti and the black fettuccini. Both dishes were delicious. However, the short rib agnolotti was clearly the stand out and probably my favorite dish here. On a past visit, I have also ordered their spaghetti which sounds plain but is super flavorful. 

We were pretty full and did not order dessert, but based on a prior visit, I highly recommend the bomboloni.

One of the most over priced Italian restaurants I've experienced. The portions were miniscule while the prices were stratospheric. The quality was so-so. My raviolis were so dry they were hard to swallow. The gingerbread desert was unremarkable for $11. Pasta dishes were in the $20-30. Better make sure there is a McDonald's in the area to hit after this dinner!!!!

i came here in a large group, and we got the private room in the back.  we had a minimum we had to meet, which i don't think was difficult.  we got a set menu w/ 4 courses.  all the courses were served family style except for the entree.  

for the first course, there was a really tasty tomato salad and a polenta w/ mushrooms.  there was also a beef and farro dish, but i didn't taste that. 

for the second course, there were 2 pastas:  the signature spaghetti, and a  tagliatelle w/ peas and guaciale.  both pastas were delicious, but i preferred the taglatelle.

my entree was the cod, which was fine but nothing to write home about.  there was also a steak option.

there were 3 desserts:  a choc cake w/ salted caramel, apple tart, and a coconut cream thing in a guava/pineapple soup.  the choc cake and apple tart were amazing.  

everyone also raved about the stromboli bread.  drinks here were good too.  i'd come back to dine in the main restaurant next time.

So much potential here, the experience was really 3 star but I'm optimistic.

Great layout with large S-curved bank seating and a nice north facing view of the Bellagio fountain. Service is great but the kitchen timing needs work. Food came out a bit slow and a bit cold which is normally a big time no-no but they are new and working out the kinks.

Food is delicious, apps of short ribs and polenta truffles with mushrooms make for a great start. Polenta was creamy and truffle accents were spot on. 

Pastas are house-made and cooked just al-dente. Easy to do but somehow few places get it right. The spaghetti with creamy tomato and basil, just perfect, a great representation of Italian food in its simplistic goodness. Black cod done well, cooked nicely. 

Duck and foie gras ravioli was a bit salty and cold and the agnolotti seemed too one dimensional. Both were slightly warm and would have been better paired with a side. Plates seemed a bit bare.

Desserts-  very creative. Napoleon-  deconstructed creme brulee with blood oranges, sweet and creamy, amazing combination. 

Nutella warm molten chocolate bites with hazelnuts were also deliciously comforting. 

Overall, given the lack of decent Italian eateries with value on the Strip, it's worth a visit. Once they get the timing down, the kitchen and the service make this a sure-bet for a quality meal.

Headed over to 500 Cucina for pizza night to try a new place.  The lighting was bright; there were TVs.  I don't know, I just can't get excited about this place.  I'm writing this review a few months after dining here and I can't remember anything about the food.  I'm sure I had pizza and it was probably good but the lighting and the TVs are all I can remember.  Maybe not a bad choice if you have a group and you're in Inglewood.  Not a great choice for date night.

Delicious! We weren't starving so asked the waiter to select four appetizers that we could easy split. Such a great idea! See the pictures but we had tuna roll, octopus, lobster pasta, shrimp and oysters followed by these little pastries similar to a donut stuffed with either chocolate or vanilla cream. It was a wonderful experience and our waiter was top notch!! I would definitely go back and recommend anyone else to also.

Late review from dinner in Feb.  

Great ambiance and view of the Bellagio fountains.   Order the duck foie gras ravioli or short rib bone marrow agnolotti.   Favors are incredible!   Even the bread basket is amazing.   Pricey but definitely worth it.   Cosmopolitan has a great selection of restaurants.

I'm a huge fan of Chopped and love Chef Scott Conant so when I heard he has two restaurants in Las Vegas I couldn't wait to try one. Let's me first share that the staff was extremely friendly and when we shared we had show reservations they were prompt and made sure we were out in time. Our table was by the window over looking the Bellagio. We had the perfect view of their water show. We asked our server what his favorite items are on the menu and he has excellent taste! Everything was simply amazing!!! From the appetizer to the pasta to the dessert. I never order spaghetti as I find it too simply but Chef Conant's is beyond amazing! It was truly the best Italian dinner I ever had!

Very expensive. $24-27 for vegetarian pasta plates. However, I enjoyed my basil tomato spaghetti. The pasta are freshly made and tasted great. The bread basket and dips were delicious. The ambience is wonderful, upscale, and unique. The service was a little slow but we had a large party. The waiters were very friendly and helpful.

After reading the most recent reviews I thought it could be a little risky but the menu looked great and the ambiance was what we were looking for to take out a client.
Bummed we ended up going.  The food wasn't great and the server was rude and clearly needed to turn the table.  He literally kept returning to the table every 2 minutes until we ordered and then would stand at the table while we were in mid conversation and I stare until we stopped talking.  Not what you expect at a nice restaurant!
We ordered the $70 porterhouse which came smothered in a cheese sauce (who puts cheese on that cut of meat?!), the cod which looked like a dry pork chop when it came and was smothered in a tomato paste, and the duck which was far from tender and cam in these two huge chunks.
All in all super disappointing.  Maybe pasta is the way to go there.

I have been waiting for this day for month.... I am back in Vegas and tonight I am having my favorite pasta ever!!! I wish I could have it twice, but was not able to get away!!!
They have the best past and polenta ever!!! I have had it twice on my last  visit and twice on my visit before! 
Black inc w uni ( plenty of it) and creamy crab is INSANE!!!!
Scarpetta, I am coming at 6pm!!!

This place is swanky/trendy so prepare to spend some serious $$. It overlooks the Bellagio fountains which is pretty cool. 
The service is extremely well-trained and professional. 
We started off not ordering drinks but felt kind of funny, almost like it was *expected* we order a cocktail. If you're concerned about the cost, just don't go here. We sucked it up and ordered 2 drinks (cocktail was $18, wine was $15). 
We started with the raw tuna appetizer with caviar, granny smith apples and truffle crema. It was delicious. It comes with 4 pieces and because we split it, they put 2 each on separate plates which was a nice touch. 
Also, to note, the bread basket is insanely good. They bring a few different types and serve it with citrus olive oil, whipped mascarpone with sea salt and a tapenade. 
I had the duck and foie gras ravioli. I did enjoy them but they were a little one note. Perhaps they could have been a little heavier handed with the balsamic drizzle for a more complex flavor? I also was pretty full at that point after eating half the bread basket. I did wrap the rest to go and they tasted really great heated the next day. 
My bf had the $55 steak which he really enjoyed but didn't understand why it was worth $55.
We finished the meal with the chocolate parfait since it was the only gluten free dessert option. It was fine. Pretty light and refreshing. 
Overall we enjoyed our experience once we got over the $$ aspect. It cost $200 for 2 people. Definitely check this place out if you are gluten free since they have many GF options. Just ask your waiter for the GF menu when you're seated. They are very accommodating.

This is hands down one of my favorite places. I love everything about it! 

The ambiance is very close and cozy, perfect for date nights or business dinner!! The staff is very sweet and they are always checking on you whether it's their table or not. 

The menu is perfect, they have a little bit of everything. For starters they have this amazing yellowtail sashimi and it melts in your mouth(one of our favs). They also have this short rib ravioli/pillow and that you must must get. I have never tasted anything more delicious in my life (we get it everytime). For their entrees they have this chicken and it's so tender and the skin is perfectly crisp.

Everytime we try something new and we are never let down! This place knows what they're doing! Can't wait to come back again!

We dined on Friday April 8 rather late in the evening.  Jason was our server.  After initially looking at the menu, I was very intrigued by the variety and interesting plates.  We decided on the octopus appetizer, which they very nicely split between two plates for me and my date so that we didn't have to do it on our own.  For an entree, I had the veal chop which came with potato mash, green peas and sweetbreads.  It was cooked to perfection and a large portion (you always worry about portion size at rather expensive restaurants, or at least I do--the last thing I want to do is leave hungry).  My date had the pork chop, which came with vegetables and an apple compote, which he said was very good.  And for dessert we had a coconut panna cotta that had grilled pineapple and a papaya "soup".  It was light and a perfect way to end the meal.  Jason was great and he had recommendations on wine pairings and helped us pick out the delish dessert.  We had a lovely view of the Bellagio fountains as well, so that was beautiful.  All in all, this was one of the best meals I've ever had, and would certainly love to return next time we are in Las Vegas--hopefully with a Chef Conant sighting next time too!

The service was very attentive, the food was out of this world and don't get me started on the desserts.  They had this amazing caramel pudding, yes pudding, that I could not stop eating!

The sommelier was pretentious but funny.  He has great recommendations once he was past the fact that, yes, we can afford what we just ordered.

I love how once the appetizers were served, they split them among everyone at the table so it was easier to share.

It really was a beautiful restaurant, romantic ambiance and fantastic food.

Long awaited dining experience!!
Scenic View. Impeccable service.
Arrived and seated in a timely manner.
The entire staff was overly accommodating and the atmosphere was both ambient without being too romantic of a setting for two.

Made it easy by handing over $300 and having the server pick out our entire six course meal. We are industry, so I am sure we we taken care of beyond that.

Yellowtail Sashimi
Risotto
Spighetti 
A delicious creamy truffle soup dish
Halibut
And lastly and Meat/steak dish which I was too stuffed to finish.

Topped the mean off with chocolate soufflé  and and parfait/sorbet desserts. 

Oh and I had a glass of Cabernet chosen my our server and "if you see kay" 

Wonderful Experience

Wow. This place is pretty expensive, but it is worth every penny. 
The service was spot on. Everything you would expect where you'll spend about $100+ per person on dinner. 
Portions are small (well actually portions are normal size, they just seem small compared to most other places that try to impress you with mediocre food by giving you a lot).  
For starters we had scallops - very good, cooked perfectly.  Seared perfectly for a nice crunch, and tender on the inside. And we had the creamy polenta with truffled mushrooms. Wow, the polenta was full of flavor, and the truffled mushrooms were amazing. One of the best things I have ever ate. 
We also had a pasta course (cannot remember what it was called), but it was almost like a ravioli and was stuffed with a meat puree of chicken and veal. The texture was super creamy, like a pate. This pasta was amazing.
We also had the duck and foie gras ravioli. Even more amazing than the previous pasta. Tender pasta, the sauce was perfect, and the duck and foie gras was in a perfect balance. 
For our main course we had 2 orders of veal loins wrapped in pancetta and served with sweetbreads and roasted vegetables. Let's just say there was nothing left on my plate. 
Next we had dessert.  Tiney doughnuts (zepolle) filled with nutella and served with cream anglaise. I was so full, but managed to eat every one. We also had the cheesecake. Which was very very good. 
This place will not disappoint. But you will spend some money. Our bill was 300 after tip, an we did not have any alcohol. Add a bottle of wine and it would have been about a 400 meal.  But no regrets. I'd go back as often as I could afford to.

Ate at Scarpetta's on a Wednesday night, week before New Year's so it wasn't packed, got seated by a really friendly hostess. Upon sitting down we were offered two types of water, nice touch. A few minutes later passed and we were greeted by the assistant manager Kelly, asked if this had been our first time and we replied yes. 

Knowing the Executive chef Dan Rossi, we were treated to having him select our food and then having his wine sommelier (Paulo) pair wines with each course. If you know very little about wines, like myself, I would highly recommend Paulo making the decisions for you, this guy is a master at his trade. Our wines complimented each course perfectly and it truly made the night one to remember. 

Trying to remember everything we ate would be a six page review so I'll just touch on a few must haves, not that we didn't thoroughly enjoy every dish, because everything was an orgasmic explosion of flavors on the tongue, but I'm going to keep this short and sweet. Polenta with a five mushroom ragu, unbelievable. Their signature spaghetti, out of this world. Ravioli's with Foie Gras and duck, I could have eaten 20. Some Carmel pudding dessert with this homemade salted Carmel toffee with crushed pretzels was insane. That was just a few of the fifteen things we got, also Fritto Misto, is a must. 

Basically your not going to go wrong with anything in this place, food is off the hook, service staff paid attention to every detail and the view of the Strip is the best. This will be on my stop every time I visit Vegas from here on out, period.

Wow.  Hands down the best restaurant I have been to in Vegas.  All of the food items were perfect.  I started with a salad with burrata, mixed greens, beets and hazelnuts - well designed and delicious.  For my main course I had the babay goat (I think it's called capreto) - also excellent.  My table companions had the branzino (delicious) and the out of this world, must have lobster with black macaroni.  The desert was a chocolate cake, but the star of the dish was actually the accompanying gelato, served on some sort of chocolate crubms - yum

the bread here deserves a paragraph by itself.  Between the three of us we ate four baskets.  There was a big piece that they put on top that was good.  Inside there was bread with some kind of meat in it, delicious rolls, and then some sort of bread that they had toasted so that it was crispy - it came out crunchy and airy and was perfect with the marscapone butter.

My only complaint is that the wait staff hover around you and the second you finish something they come in an snatched the plate away.  It was very noticable - do they think that this constitutes good service?  But our waiter was excellent.  They have a good wine list, and the prices are good for this quality of food

So definitely go go go!

I have now been here a few times and enjoy the food overall but the first time dining at this place was a huge disappointment.  

Made a reservation for Valentine's dinner so I was super excited to try out this restaurant with my husband but the host lost our reservation and when we arrived they made us wait for over 45 minutes.  We were both starving at this point but waited patiently and when they finally sat us we got seated in the entrance area in the corner which wasn't very romantic at all.  The food also took forever which made us even more annoyed.  

I decided to try this restaurant a few times after this incident and have had a better experience so I do think they have improved.  

The ambiance in this restaurant is actually very nice and enjoyable.

We came here twice.  The second time service was awesome!  The waiter we had was so attentive and cool as in hip to everything.  The food was amazing and deliciously consistent with the New York location, but you're in Vegas!!!  
It's nice they have seasonal items so there is always something new to try.  I started with the autumn vegetable soup (dreamy and creamy), my husband had the tartart special.  He loved it and wouldn't share.  Then we had a pasta course, I can't stop getting the spaghetti.....i can't!  Colin got the short rib agnolotti, which was very buttery good...  Then we had the nerve to share the 24 oz ribeye,  it was soooooo good, tender and perfectly seasoned.  We actually ate it all!  plus the sides, horseradish mashed potatoes....

Mario, the manager was extremely nice and helped us out with a service problem we experienced on our last visit and made everything perfect for this visit.  We did not expect the extra desserts brought out for us to try.  You have to try the little donuts (bomboloni) and the coconut panacotta was very tropical with a guava sauce...My favorite group, Depeche Mode was playing and when they found out, they changed the playlist to only play their songs!  
There are so many choices of places to try in Vegas and this is a must.  Worth every penny and worth several more visits.

Deeeeelicious restaurant. Everything from the delicious bread they serve ahead of the meal down to the actual espresso. My husband and his parents are Italian and they were pretty impressed with the ingredients. 
However, to give a accurate review let me tell you in detail what made us take off one star.
To have an Italian restaurant, at least make the menu accurate. PRIMI means PASTA dishes in Italy. Not appetizers. Please adjust so it feels authentic! Secondo are the carne...meats.

Pasta was cooked perfect al dente but lacking a little salt. Servers were very attentive, but I think we had about 3 or 4 different people ask if everything was ok, including a man in a suit. That's a bit much but if they just want to make sure we are ok then I am fine with that haha.
My mother in law and myself ordered the vegetable Tagliatelle and it was perfect (minus the salt).
My father in law had the pici but was disappointed, he said there was no taste.
Husband had the duck and foie gras and was very happy, it was tasty but hard to digest. 

We ordered 3 contorni: mushrooms; they had zero taste. Creamer potatoes; best thing from all the contorni, but that's sad cause they are in the end just potatoes. And last, we had Broccolini. No taste and a little raw.

For a celebrity chef owning the restaurant, he could kick it up a notch for the contorni.

Honestly, I wasn't expecting great food from a swanky restaurant in Las Vegas on the strip... but I was wrong. Scarpetta offers wonderful Italian food at reasonable prices, for the quality and service.

Their bread is to die for... Seriously, I could eat a loaf of that gooey, spinach bread with butter. I also loved the rosemary foccacia.

We enjoyed the tuna appetizer, the filet, and their signature spaghetti dish and everything was perfectly executed and delicious.

The bombino (sp?) dessert was a great way to end the meal.

Honestly, we had zero complaints and just had a really wonderful dinner.

Highly recommended!
Great service and well thought out menu and flavored. The pasta was perfectly made. Our favorite was an uni and crab squid ink pasta.

In short; the food was five stars, the service was three stars. 

I can't say enough about the food! We loved it! Unfortunately we had really bad service. We had two guys waiting on us. I don't know if the main waiter was busy or they were training, but it was obvious the second guy was more junior. He was trying to avoid saying, 'I don't know'. For example we asked what the parts were in the lamb three ways dish. We were told chops, short rib, and one other part that I can't remember right now. The chops made sense. When I commented that short rib was usually beef he agreed. So I said 'the lamb three way includes beef (which I don't eat)?'  He said yes. This sounded weird to us so we asked the first waiter and got a completely different answer. The dish included chops, shoulder, and a third type, maybe shank or something. Ultimately we decided against the lamb so I can't tell you what was really in it. 

For appetizers we got yellowtail. There was three of us and I believe the portion came with five pieces. Instead of giving us an extra piece to round it out, they gave us three pieces and kept two in the kitchen. That seemed odd so we questioned it. The junior waiter apologized and said the kitchen staff was new. Who knows!!

The yellowtail was good and an additional serving came out of the kitchen. 

We knew we had to try a pasta dish here as they are all handmade and Scott Conant does Italian food so well. We had a few dietary restrictions at the table so we ordered the tagliatelle. We were told that it came with short rib, but it could be brought on the side since I didn't eat beef. The pasta arrived and it was delicious!!!! We were told the kitchen was figuring out the short rib for us. Guess what? It never arrived! I wasn't surprised at this given how everything else was going. In fact I knew we were being duped the minute the waiter said it. The pasta was so good on its own so we didn't miss it or bring it up, but it was another problem with the service. 

For entrees two of us got the halibut and it was amazing! My husband got one of the two beef dishes. The waiters disagreed on which one was liked best by patrons, but there weren't any problems with the dishes coming out incomplete. 

For dessert we got the bomboloni. Oooh they were divine!

So again, food was top notch. There was not one thing that we did not like. I'm hoping service was only off the night we went. We weren't put off by it. We were actually laughing at everything that happened. It's a must try restaurant in my books.

Great Italian food here. I have to warn others that the portion is very small!!! I got the steak and my friend got a pasta ravioli. We were planning to share it but my steak was literally 5 pieces after I cut it, and her ravioli was 5 pieces. We both had 5 bites total. The food was sooo good. But why is it so small??

This review is for 4.5 stars.

Some of the best pasta I have ever eaten.  You can tell it was freshly prepared and so much better than any other pasta you've ever had.  The service was strong, maybe a little too intrusive at times, but overall very good.  

We went with the polenta with mushrooms as an appetizer, spaghetti, and duck ravioli.  The bread bowl to begin was just your typical bread.  I'm not sure why there is such great reviews for it but it was pretty average, albeit perfect dipping utensils for our appetizer.  The polenta was a great started and had a cream of mushroom taste.  The spaghetti was the best spaghetti I've ever had but it's still very plain.  The ravioli was wonderful.  A little chewy inside with freshly made pasta.  And it was actually quite filling which was very surprising considering ravioli is usually a small dish with only about 5-6 large pieces.  This dish came with about 20 medium sized.  I recommend that dish to anyone.  

They have an extensive wine menu specializing in Italy but from all over the world.  This is one of your better Italian restaurants on the strip.  It has the European feel not the New York feel, so if that is the type of cuisine you're after, then give it a try.  It will run you at least $30/entree, $15-20 for appetizers, and $15 for a single drink.  My tip is to make a reservation and try to get a view of the Bellagio fountains.

Great atmosphere, great service and great food.  Who could ask for more?  And we didn't even have any of Chef Scott Conant's famous pasta.  If so, this would probably be the first 6-star rating on YELP.

Not cheap but definitely worth the money.  An experience I would gladly do over and over again!

Wife and I decided to try this establishment during our trip to Vegas, first weekend of April.  All I can say is from top to bottom, fantastic.  The ambiance, the service, the food all top rate.  The greeter/hostess at the door wasn't overly warm but I can get over that usually if the food and ambiance is good.  

We could only get a 6 pm seating on a Thursday (and I booked a week ahead) so I thought that was a good sign.  When we got there it was EMPTY.  We got a great seat by the window.   It started to fill up during our seating.  We got a fantastic basket of breads and spreads almost right away.  The best bread I have ever had in a restaurant bar none.  I could go either way on bread before a meal, but this was outstanding.  

My wife got the Tagliatelle which was light, yet filling enough for her to be full enough so I could play clean up at the end.  It was fantastic.  I had the duck and foie gras ravioli.  WOW.  Had a wonderful balsamic like reduction on.  They don't wow you with portion sizes, but I did not think one "boy am I getting ripped off here."  Honestly the last thing I like doing is wasting food and in Vegas I don't want to be walking around with a to go box after a meal.  I'd say it was perfect portion sizes for the dollar.  

The service was superb.  Almost too good.   We were in and out in an hour which was a little disappointing because we had a great seat in the place.  But that is the business.  Turn over.  I will say we didn't linger either as it was our first night in las vegas.  

Definitely Recommended for people who want more from their pasta than the Olive Garden has to offer.

Scarpetta is all hype and price - not worth either.

The space is cold and vacuous. - not as scenster or happening as I would have expected.  Everyone seemed over dressed - like they were on a big night out from the burbs...not at all like the vibe on the roof top.  Reminded me of Vegas or the Time Warner Center in NYC - a fake environment plopped down in a hotel.   We had a group of 12 in the private room and they limited our choices - always annoying!  Wines were overly marked up - 10$ more than other restaurants - really expensive menu - and the quality and presentation was hardly amazing.  Price for the sake of price.

My spaghetti was very good - much better than the beef tenderloin most people ordered - if you go, get pasta...even at 30plus a bowl it is a better option!

I won't return.  Not an authentic spot and not worth the moola.

A new Vegas restaurant that's not ready for the big time yet. I find owners and management of restaurants that originate in NYC tend to run their restaurants the same way here in Vegas and in general the wrong way here on the west coast. Management is rude and thus rubs off on their employees. Service is slow and we found ourselves asking for everything water, drinks, desert menu etc....small portions and ridiculously high prices. Food was luke warm and unseasoned. chocolate cake for desert was good. This place has a long way to go. Stay away and eat at one of the other 100 great restaurants Vegas has to offer.

After years of wanting to dine at Scarpetta, my husband pleasantly surprised me for our Anniversary dinner. We had reservations (highly recommend), and were seated by the window with an enchanting Strip view overlooking the Bellagio fountains. The server promptly greeted us to take our drink order - their wine and cocktail menu had a nice selection.  Another server dropped off a bread basket filled with a warm variety (including spinach filled foccacia, sourdough, and a salami baked roll), along with marscapone infused butter, and citrus olive oil for dipping. Service was attentive and the ambience romantic. For an appetizer we tried the Frito Misto (lightly fried veggies, calamari, and shrimp). Our main entrées were Kobe flat iron (seasoned well and accompanied by creamy gnocchi) and short rib aglonotti (which was rich in consistency and flavor from the brown butter and horseradish breadcrumbs). Our evening was memorable, and the chef has done well for himself here.
Black Tagliolini - Best uni pasta I've ever had. Uni, crab, and tobiko mixed together. It's was the bomb pasta, seafood freshness with classic pasta

I was so excited to go to Scarpetta and I was not disappointed. Our server was so personable and helpful. He recommended a bottle of wine that went perfectly with our meal. On top of that, when we mentioned how were interested in the wine industry, he went out of his way to write down a couple of documentaries for us to watch. Just above and beyond.  The heirloom tomato salad is just indescribable. The best salad I've ever had. I had one of the specials of the night--  pappardelle with burrata and prosciutto in a tomato sauce.  So great. I really wanted to try the spaghetti, but my dining partner forgot to share. It was that good.  Overall, great!

Had dinner here with a few friends. Started with the truffled polenta and "suschi", then we had a ravioli and followed with the fillet. The raviolis were under cooked and we definitely should have sent them back but that was our fault.  Everything else was really nice but my biggest complaint is that the polenta, ravioli and fillet all had the same demi glace. It was too rich after the second dish and my taste buds got totally bored.  For the price I would go else where.

Came here for dinner and was blown away by the view. You can see the Bellagio fountains from the side. Make sure to ask to sit by the window. The lighting in the restaurant was a bit dark to see exactly what you are eating but the food was great. Not mind blowing, but great.

Bread service (complimentary) - was fantastic. I loved the variety.
Scallops ($23) - were cooked perfectly but I've had better back home in SF.
Creamy polenta ($18) - was really smooth and tasty. I think it needed a pinch of salt but this was our 2nd fave of the night.
Spaghetti with tomato and basil ($24) - was not mind blowing but it's the best dish of the night and I can see why people are crazy about it.
Pici ($36) - tasted fine but the spaghetti tasted better.
Black cod ($33) - was good but not memorable.
Chocolate souffle ($15) - typical souffle but it was properly made which I appreciated. It was big, enough for the two of us.

Service was fantastic, we shared everything and our server had most of the dishes come already split. We never felt abandoned. Someone would always be around to make sure our glasses are full. Portion size is on the larger size which is great to see nowadays. We didn't know this so we over ordered by about two dishes.

We have great modern italian restaurants back home (SPQR, Quince, Flour + Water) so my standards are a bit high. I do however still recommend this place if you were craving for modern italian.

The place looks dressy but we came in jeans and were fine. There were others in jeans as well. And of course there were some who were WAY over dressed.

Yelped this place and saw some good reviews so I booked a reservation on my birthday during Memorial Day weekend. I loved the view, we sat right next to the window viewing the bellagio fountain. The food was OK , I ordered the pasta and I just did not like the taste of it, it had no flavor and I just tasted better. Now for the service I get it was a holiday weekend but the stuck up hostess just ruined the whole experience for me, came a little early and asked if it's possible if we can sit next to the window and she told us no it was not possible even though I made sure to book a table right next to a window on the reservation notes ? Luckily the manager was standing right behind her and told us there was a table available right now next to a window so me and my husband just agreed to be seated already. I just rolled my eyes at that rude host and walked away while the manager walked us to the table.

The food and the ambiance were 5 stars!  I really liked the décor here, someone put a lot of thought into the design, it's sexy and sophisticated.  To drink I had a whiskey cocktail off their menu, it was tasty.  For dinner I had a duck and foie gras ravioli which was sooo yum, the picture I took doesn't do it justice.  The service was just okay.

The worst part about Scarpetta is that you eventually have to leave. It was a sad moment when I took my last bite of amazingness and realized I was already having separation anxiety with my Duck and foie gras ravioli. Not to mention the mouth orgasm I had after over indulging in the Bombolini dessert with nutella dust. (Went back the following night for an encore performance ). I am not going to sit here all day and rave about how perfect the beef tartare was or how life altering the short rib angolottis were, but what i will do is tell anyone who has anything bad to say about Scarpetta, you honestly don't have a clue what good food is all about. I just read 30 reviews and one person had said "The duck ravioli flat out sucked" Dude STFU and have some respect. I guarantee you are the type of DB that enjoys the food at Olive garden. Get a grip. Here is my run down from a foodie who has traveled the world in search of great cuisine and spend 10 years running kitchens:

Service-
From the hostess to the table service, everything surpassed my high expectations. Very attentive without being over bearing. Luis was very sociable and you could tell he wasn't trying to up-sell anything and he gave his honest opinion when needed. Very knowledgeable about the menu and was honestly fantastic.

Ambiance-
Very comfortable, modern atmosphere complimented by great music and bellaggio fountains.

Food Quality-
FRESH PASTA! Come on how can you complain about fresh pasta  I guess if you like rubber olive garden garbage pasta and you didn't enjoy the king of pasta's execution then your review is null.

Overall Food Experience-
There is only one way to sum up Scarpetta so the common man can understand how great this experience is: 

If you like the fake bread sticks and man made olive oil at Olive garden then you aren't going to like the FRESH baked bread and stromboli complimented by lemon olive oil, eggplant capanata, or marscapone butter.

If you like frozen pasta that been frost bitten for 2 years, then your aren't going to enjoy fresh made pasta stuffed with delicate meats such as duck or short rib.

If you go to the outback and are really wowed by the meat quality then you aren't going to understand the complexity of meat that they use here. 

So for you complaining feeble minded yelpers, stay away from Scarpetta, you do not deserve to enjoy and embrace what this amazing restaurant has to offer. To the foodies who share my same enthusiasm for this amazing restaurant, you know how excited I am to go back.

What is with me and over-hyped restaurants for the end of 2012?  Scarpetta definitely belongs in this category based on the taste vs price category.  I mean, the restaurant looked nice, and the service was decent (if not spotty)...but the food just didn't do it.

Here's what I got to try:
Bread:  Bread was good, but not amazing like how some reviewers portrayed it.  I will give points to them having stromboli  =)  .

Fritto Misto : Nice portion size but $17 for fried seaweed (super oily) with little bits of shrimp?

Scallops: Smelled great and was very tasty.   $17 for two scallops.

Raw Yellowtail: $16 for 4 REALLY thin slices of yellowtail.  Jaws not happy.  #AVOID

Spaghetti:  At $24, I expected my mind to be blown into spaghetti heaven, maybe even meeting the dogs from Lady and the tramp.  However, I was really underwhelmed by the sauce.  There was little to no seasoning so basically all I was tasting was a bit of crushed tomatoes, cheese, with bits of basil.  Simplicity does not mean bland.  The noodles were cooked al dente and had a nice texture, so that is the lone bright spot. Ugh....BLAND BLAND BLAND.

Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli: $26.  Foie Gras in a ravioli? Must be amazing right?  Instead it was so dry that I felt like I was eating melted sand paper.  I thought duck meat was supposed to be tender and juicy?  I guess mixing duck meat and foie gras was a bad move.  The marsala reduction was delightful as I wish there was more of it to compensate for the dryness of the filling.

Roasted Chicken : Finally, a delicious dish.  It was cooked perfectly and finally seasoned correctly.  I don't mind paying a pretty penny for food...as long as its delicious!  But do keep in mind that this was still $29.  

Chocolate cake: Standard.

Doughnuts with filling:  It is what it is.  Doughnuts tossed in sugar with chocolate/vanilla filling.  I couldn't overlook that this dish was COLD when we ate it.  I understand that the filling could have caused that...but still... doughnuts should at least be warm!

Bottom line: Good environment, spotty service, and overhyped and expensive food give this place 2 stars.

Ugh, pretty disappointed with this place.  We should have chosen somewhere else to have our "nice" dinner to celebrate our friends anniversary.

Our party of 4 booked a reservation on OpenTable the night before, and 8:30pm was the only timeslot left available.  Everything went smooth upon checking in.  They serve complimentary bread which is actually a variety of different breads which was pretty cool.   Unfortunately that was just about the only good thing of the evening.

The entire night we felt rushed by the waiters and the staff. Our waiter seemed impatient while we were ordering and even when they brought the food out, they would come up from behind us and put the food on the table and then disappear. It took forever to get more bread and refills on water.  Our waiter seemed irritated when we asked for more bread.

As for the food, it was meh. The best tasting thing was our appetizer, the grilled octopus and squid ($20).  For entree, I ordered the foie gras ravioli ($28) since I'd never tried foie gras before.  If it's supposed to taste wonderful, then I obviously ordered the wrong dish.  I didn't even eat half.  The two boys at our table ordered the Short Rib Agnolotti ($26) and it was good for the first few bites, but the taste was bland after you ate a few.  They didn't finish their pasta either.

I've definitely been better to Italian places, with much better service as well. Definitely won't be back.

Fantastic service, delicious drinks, great atmosphere, but let's be honest what's the primary reason for going to a nice restaraunt?  The food.  

We'll keep it simple, the food was meh for the price, and we are the type of people who are easily pleased. We started with the spiced artichoke soup.  It was brought out looking beautiful but it was bland:  light, but very subtle on the artichoke flavor and little to no "spice."  Our entrees were the tomato basil spaghetti and the tagiatelle, a truffle pasta with veggies.  For $24 and $27 respectively we were expecting the best tomato basil pasta and truffle pasta we ever had.  Unfortunately we were not blown away.  Neither dish had anything special going on with them, other than the spaghetti being a perfect al dente.  Then we chose the chocolate cake served with an almond gelato and salted caramel.  Nothing special, seriously so dissappointed, although "happy anniversary" was written so beautifully on the plate it almost made up for it.  Looking back we should have gotten the bananas fosters because we heard about how great it is but unfortunately we didn't, because my wife wanted chocolate.  We were told the soufflé (bananas fosters), marscapone cheesecake, and the filled doughnuts were the top 3 deserts.

We appreciated the staff and the service and we tipped well at the end because of it, however when you spend $150 on a meal, with just 2 drinks, you just expect a bit more from the food.

Beautiful restaurant but overrated . The waiter rush us to order after giving us the menu . When we asked what was good he rushing us . He seems distracted when the restaurant wasn't busy . I ordered wine than he took the menu and didn't bother to ask the rest of the party what they wanted. So I had to ask him to take the others drink order. 
We were hoping food would be amazing after the bad service , sadly it wasn't even good . Everything was salty. My party and I drank so much water .
Maybe chef had a bad bay .

I had HIGH expectations coming to this place. EXTREMELY high expectations. For all the attention to detail and harsh criticisms that Scott has on Chopped, I anticipated a true culinary masterpiece. 

My girlfriend and I weren't that hungry, because we had already had an early dinner, but decided to give this place a shot because it was the only day that would have worked with our trip to Las Vegas. We thought the best thing to do would be to just order an appetizer and only one course each, as opposed to the traditional multiple courses with a true Italian meal. We ordered the short ribs as an appetizer, I ordered the spaghetti and my girlfriend ordered the roasted chicken.

The best part of the meal was the bread. You heard me. The BEST part of the meal was the bread. I must say, I had high hopes going in, higher hopes after the bread, because that was good bread. The focaccia was tasty, with the right amount of rosemary and well developed. It tasted fresh and airy. The other breads were also very good. 

We got our appetizer, and it was very small - which is usual for a good Italian place, since it's expected that you order multiple courses. This wasn't an appetizer though, it was basically an amuse-bouche. The ribs had good flavor, and the risotto was good as well, it good texture, but I would have liked it to be cooked a little longer - it wasn't crunchy, but it was still slightly underdone. 

Out come our main courses. 

My pasta is placed on the table, and the server removes the cloche. My first impression? "This is a main course?" I counted how many bites it took me to finish that pasta, and it was nine. Literally nine. It was such a small meal that I was still slightly hungry afterwards - even though I wasn't all that hungry coming in. And as for the flavor? I think Barilla pasta and Prego sauce tastes about the same, as long as you add some fresh basil, which was the only saving grace. But for $24, this was ludicrous. The pasta was just about al dente as well, so there was good texture. And as for the chicken? Horrible. Absolutely horrible. And small. I asked the server about the preparation, and he noted that it is brined with anise and some other flavors, which were conspicuously missing from the flavor of the dish. I ended up spending around $80 on just these three items, and definitely was left wondering why. Scarpetta gets the award for most over-promised, under-delivered food experience I've had so far. It was so bad that any time I see Scott on Chopped or any other show, I feel like he has no idea what he is talking about. Avoid this place, and go to Secret Pizza just down the hall instead - you'll save money, eat tastier food, and leave with a better experience.

I find it sad that some people haven't had a great experience at this restaurant.  I found the service attentive and friendly, the space gorgeous, and the food exceptional.  Having said that, the food wasn't without flaw - the frito was salty (for me, that's a rare complaint).  The star of my evening was the spaghetti with tomato/basil - it was cooked so perfectly and the flavor was nothing less than spectacular.  I know, I know...  it is just spaghetti.  But if you are a fan of pasta, just try it.  You'll see.  Our party also had scallops, a couple wagu ribeyes, chicken, lamb - all of it was great.

Amazing food and amazing service. Ask for Server Julian, he is one of the best. He is on top of your needs and has great recommendations. We had an awesome time. Bar tender made some great drinks too. Highly recommend this place.

High quality food delivered very poorly.

This restaurant came recommended by a foodie friend I trust. After eating at a lot of great places on the strip, I had high expectations. My friend got the food right but our overall experience was greatly lacking.

After explaining to our server that we had no other places to be, I expected a slow, thoughtful dinner where we could savor each course. Rather it felt like the staff was trying to flip the table. Everyone in our party of four felt like the food was being served without passion. A full course meal for four was served and eaten in about an hour. I was hoping for at least a relaxing two-hour dinner. 

The food itself was quite good--not the best we've had on our trip to Vegas--but delightful. The price we paid seemed a bit on the high side for the quality of food but for the most part seemed appropriate. The foie gras ravioli is a must do.

Our server was polite but inattentive. One drink we ordered (mine) failed to make it to the table--an honest enough mistake as these oversights can happen now and then. However the server failed to notice and not once throughout the entire meal checked on drinks. I completed my meal without ever getting a beverage. When I was charged for the drink and the error was called out, the server made no effort to make it right.

The support staff was overly attentive. Empty plates were cleared promptly. However my unfinished main dish was almost taken twice before I was finished. I had to stop the food from being cleared before I was done enjoying it. Again, it seemed like they were trying to flip the table. One of the support staff also topped my unfinished sparkling water with tap.

Plate prices are on the high side and the many missteps were inconsistent with the quality I expected. There are myriad great places to eat in Vegas and service is a key differentiator. You can find better, more unique food to enliven your palate and, based on our time there, more invested humans to help you experience it.

This place is amazing!!

I arrived with a group of 8 others and we were sat at the chef's table, which is through restaurant and kitchen in a little room. The room is overlooking the whole strip with the bellagio fountain nearest. 

We started with a bunch of appetizers: tuna, oysters, octopus, bread, beef tartare. We actually ordered 3 dishes of the tuna bc it was so good. 

For the mains, people got the branzino, pasta, steak, lobster. Everything was so tasty except the steak was pretty well done when asked for medium rare. We got some side potatos, greens and mushrooms as well. 

The wine selection was perfect and service was great. I will definitely be returning back! I also love the cosmo hotel.

I took my husband here for his 30th birthday last weekend.  Located in the Cosmopolitan, this restaurant is upscale and super trendy.  The bill was super pricey, but it was worth every penny.  We would go back in a heartbeat!

Dimly lit and super chic, this place fits right into the Cosmopolitan!  We were seated right next to a window that overlooks the Bellagio fountains.  We got to enjoy the show a few times during our dinner, absolutely beautiful.  The only eye sore is that down below are the "hidden" extra plants, dirt, etc that the surrounding resorts use.

A basket of five different types of bread is served with citrus olive oil, mascarpone butter, and eggplant/olive/tomato spread.  These were all absolutely amazing and they brought us another basket of bread for our meal.  This was a nice, unexpected treat!

For our primi piatti, we ordered the creamy polenta. It is usually served in a large bowl to share among the table, but they separated it for us.  The taste was so luxurious.  I could have made this my entire meal--I would highly recommend it!

For our entrees, my husband ordered their spaghetti.  This is one of their most well known dishes and it did not disappoint.  The best spaghetti I've ever tasted, hands down.  I ordered the Duck & Foie Gras Ravioli and it was perfection.  The ravioli practically melted in your mouth.  I would definitely recommend both of these options!

For dessert, we ordered the Strawberry Souffle served with vanilla gelato & berries.  The best souffle I've ever had.  My husband, who isn't a sweets person, said it might be the best thing he has ever tasted.  This is a big deal coming from him.  

It was an amazing evening and this dinner was a huge part of it.  The only reason I didn't give the restaurant a 5 star review, is because I found a piece of bone in my ravioli that hurt my tooth.  When you are paying for a fancy dinner like that, you don't expect these types of things to happen.  Regardless of that slip-up, it was amazing and I'm already craving it again!

Try to go in a group. I've been here twice, once with my lovely wife and once with a bunch of coworkers. This is definitely a group restaurant. Please order the spaghetti. Then, order it again, and then take an order for carry out!

I was lucky enough to spend a semester studying abroad in Rome and Sicily, it was easily the greatest experience of my life. Ever since I have been on never ending search to find an Italian restaurant that can match the authentic flavors that Italy is famous for.... the search is over, Scarpetta is that restaurant. 

Squid ink pasta is a staple of Italian cuisine, yet it's almost impossible to find on a menu in the states. Scarpetta does it justice. The "black fettuccine" is cooked to perfection and topped with king crab, squid, shrimp, and lobster corral breadcrumbs... ho l'acquolina in bocca. 

Scarpetta also has the best Italian dessert I have tasted in years. The bomboloni is heavenly. They are nutella filled donuts lightly fried and served with banana gelato. They conjure up memories of sitting on the banks of the Tevere river eating bomboloni and people watching in the Italian sun. 

La vita è breve, festeggiare con gli amici, l'amore come non c'è domani.

5 stars for the food 
0 for the service!!!!  (and if there was anything below 0, that would be it!) 

I saw the famous Scarpetta spaghetti on Food Network's "The Best Thing I Ever Ate" and since that episode, I have been obsessed with going to Scarpetta. So excited that one opened up in Beverly Hills last October! However, I've been too busy to make the drive out there. 

I was in Vegas for 1 night on April 1st and while wandering around The Cosmpolitan Hotel, saw Scarpetta! Super excited! Made reservations for 8PM. Arrived on time and was seated promptly. Then waited, waited and waited! Really, 10 minutes before our waitress even came by our table (and empty seats all around us at this time)! Mind you, we had a 10PM show so I kept looking at the time... She took our drink order then returned 15 minutes later with our drinks!!! So almost 8:30 and have not even placed our order. She says she'll be "right back" and another 10 minutes.... Ahh, if it weren't for that spaghetti, we would have walked out! So 35 minutes after we arrived, she takes our order. 

Spaghetti for me and braised short ribs of beef for my husband. OMG.. our food arrived at out table at 9:30! Ate fast (because we had tickets to a show at 10). BTW, the food was amazing!!!! 

Had to ask another waiter to find our waitress so we can get the check. She came back to our table at 9:50 (without the check of course) and I explained again we had a 10PM show (which we ended up being late for) and needed to get out of there! 

So the food was as good as I thought it woud be but the service (or lack of) ruined my first Scarpetta experience :(

Had a birthday dinner for 9 people for 8:30 pm on a Friday night.  By the time our party arrived and we were seated it was 9:00 pm, and this was not an issue.  The server was very attentive and carefully took our orders, making helpful suggestions.  When queried about wines, the sommelier was sent our way -- and proceeded to make excellent white and red recommendations tailored to our likes.

The meal itself was well presented, and quite good.  The short rib I had for a primi was well portioned and had a delicate blend of flavors.  The spaghetti which was highlighted as the signature dish was quite good and subtle in its preparation, with the tomato and basil flavors present but not overpowering.  At our instruction, the server even had a chocolate dessert with candle brought out for the birthday girl.

Overall, it was an excellent albeit pricey meal.  Expect about $100/person for both appetizer, entree and wine.

Is it bad if you go to a restaurant in Vegas that you've been to elsewhere? I don't care. My sister and I went here for an incredible dinner. The service was fantastic. We were seated next to the window so we got to watch the fountains the entire night (contrary to what you might expect I did not get bored watching them over and over again). We started with the polenta w/mushrooms because I love it, the yellowtail, which was delicious and super fresh, and the scallops which were awesome. My sister had the infamous spaghetti which she loved (and I did too). My dish was out of control - it is called the black macaroni and if I could eat it all the time I would. It is squid ink pasta (not macaroni) with lobster and BASIL BREAD CRUMBS. I cannot describe how perfect this dish is - or how obsessed I now am with basil bread crumbs. Truly amazing. We got the zeppole for dessert. *Love* - truly excellent and wonderful - I wasn't expecting this level of awesome. I need to go to the one in nyc now so I can have the trifecta.

great spot in Cosmopolitan.  Maybe best Italian on the strip.  I had the black cod which I would get again.  Pasta was also outstanding.  Cool, dark space with  view of Bellagio fountains.  Good spot for couples.

Food was good. Had a party of 10 so got a really cool room with the view of the Bellagio fountain. 
Wine list wasn't very good for us as we typically order sub $100 bottles. Except for a few, most was at least $100+. That's disappointing. 

Had a good time. Service was great. Food was good. Our $110 bottle of wine recommended by the sommelier was not.

This place is ridiculously pricey for what it is. The menu is small and simple, so every dish feels somewhat unjustified. We tried the spaghetti, which was super plain - literally just noodles, a light tomato sauce, and some basil. Granted, it was well-made, as the noodles were cooked perfectly al dente. But seriously...I don't think anyone should have to pay close to $20 for a mere plate of noodles, especially one that doesn't even have protein. We also tried a short rib dish in an attempt to get in some protein, but the portion size was laughable and the short ribs weren't even that good. I've had much better short ribs at other New American restaurants before. Had we not been staying at The Cosmo, I definitely would have gone elsewhere for my Italian fix instead, considering how expensive and just whatevers this place is. Do yourself a favor and skip it!

The last time I went to dinner with the girls it was a wreck. We did not receive proper service being dolled up for dinner as we was. And the food was heavily overpriced for the quality it was.. I had the foie gras, it was pretty mediocre and bit salty. My side dish of spinach was very salty... Not sure I'll come back for another girl's dinner next time I'm in vegas.

I must say, I've been looking forward to visiting my favorites chefs restaurants in Las Vegas. I was thoroughly disappointed at the pasta preparation at Scarpetta. My pasta was actually crunchy, not al dente, Mr. Conant. My wife enjoyed the lamb ravioli, but agreed the pasta was undercooked. 
Talk to your chefs.

The service was VERY slow.  The potato chips were great.  

The food was OK but nothing memorable.

My wife had halibut which was overcooked.  I had a short rib pasta that was OK.

We DID love this eggplant dipping sauce and bread.  That was great!

Restaurant Week 2011. The wife and I only planned on going out only once for Restaurant Week, but after perusing all the menus we were persuaded to try one more place -- Scarpetta at the Cosmopolitan. We were seated at a two-top by the window overlooking the Bellagio fountains. One of the better views in town, it makes for a great spot for a romantic night out. The clean lines and modern motif of the restaurant interior add to the upscale and elegant atmosphere.

Scarpetta might have one of the best bread baskets around, but that can solely be attributed to the stromboli found within. Warm, chewy and delicious, it's almost a meal itself. The focaccia isn't bad either.

The first two dishes were yellowtail and polenta.
